u'programming', u'category', u'software', u'review'])
Row(id=32783, title=u'Antisemitism and the New Testament', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\nIt has been argued that the New Testament contributed toward subsequent antisemitism in the Christian community.<ref name="Dunn">James Dunn (theologian) (ed.) 1992 https://books.google.com/books?id=9zCh9SBb6Y8C&pg=PA179 J. The Question of Anti-Semitism in the New Testament Writings of the Period,  in James D.G. Dunn, \u2018Jews and Christians: the parting of the ways, CE 70 to 135. Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 1999. Pp.176-211 p 179. The challenge thus posed to Christian NT scholars in particular cannot therefore be ducked... The question we must face, then, is whether such attitudes are already inseparable from the scriptures on which they were based. ... in terms of the present inquiry, Does the attitude to Jews in the post-70 NT documents indicate that the final breach, the decisive parting of the ways between Christianity and (rabbinic) Judaism, has already happened? The idea that the New Testament is anti-Semitic is  a controversy that has emerged with force in the aftermath of the Holocaust. It is often associated with a thesis put forward by Rosemary Ruether,<ref>Rosemary Ruether https://books.google.com/books?id=XNJJAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA23  Faith and Fratricide: The Theological Roots of Anti-Semitism, Wipf and Stock Publishers, 1996  pp.23ff.<ref>John G. Gager, https://books.google.com/books?id=FGuCX_CwelAC&pg=PA13 The Origins of Anti-Semitism: Attitudes toward Judaism in Pagan and Christian Antiquity,  Oxford University Press, 1985 pp.13ff. and the various positions depend on how anti-Semitism is defined, and on scholarly disagreements over whether anti-Semitism has a monolithic continuous history, or is an umbrella term gathering in many distinct kinds of hostility to Jews over time.\n\nAccording to Louis Feldman, if anti-Semitism is an irrational outlook branding Jews as uniquely evil or inferior, such an attitude was not common in the ancient pagan world, apart from a popular form of anti-Semitism in Egypt. Technically, the proper term is, he thinks, Anti-Judaism.<ref>Louis Feldman, https://books.google.com/books?id=pACJYw0bg3QC&pg=PA277 Studies in Hellenistic Judaism, BRILL 1996 pp.277f. and n.1:Of course, the term anti-Semitism is an absurdity which the Jews took over from the Germans. There was no such thing in antiquity, since its basis, the Machic family tree, was hardly known outside the circles of the Jews themselves, until the rise of Christianity, which could not well be hostile to the race of its savior. The more accurate term would be \u201canti-Judaism\u201d but the term \u201canti-Semitism\u201d is so widespread that it may seem artificial to discard it.\u2019 The distinction between anti-Judaism and anti-Semitism is often made, or challenged,<ref>David Luckensmeyer, https://books.google.com/books?id=0KuT2qkhtGEC&pg=PA167  pp.167-171. with regard to early Christian hostility to Jews: some, notably Gavin I. Langmuir,<ref>Avner Falk, https://books.google.com/books?id=VWL4ja2BbnEC&pg=PA8 Anti-semitism: A History and Psychoanalysis of Contemporary Hatred, ABC-CLIO, 2008 pp.6-8 prefer anti-Judaism, implying theological enmity and taking anti-Semitism as anachronistic for the period,<ref>Guy Stroumsa, \u2018From anti-Judaism to antisemitism in Early Christianity,\u2019 in  Ora Limor, Guy Stroumsa, https://books.google.com/books?id=X-yF4wPWF5EC&pg=PA5 Contra Iudaeos: Ancient and Medieval Polemics Between Christians and Jews, :de:Mohr Siebeck Verlag 1996 pp.1-26  p.5: It  obviously  makes little sense to speak of Christian anti-Semitism in the earliest stages of the new religion, since the belief in Jesus Christ was at first held within a Jewish sectarian movement . .Anti-Judaism is hence perceived as inherent to Christianity, while antisemitism would represent an attitude of a rather different nature, appearing later, and elsewhere implying the secular biological race theories of modern times.<ref>Ruth Sheridan https://books.google.com/books?id=TdoyAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA38 Retelling Scripture: The Jews and the Scriptural Citations in John 1:19-12:15, BRILL, 2012 Rev.ed. pp.38 f. Sheridan  argues the dichotomy is problematic  Peter Sch\xe4fer prefers the word Judaeophobia for pagan hostility to Jews, but considers the word antisemitism, even if anachronistic, synonymous with this term, while adding that  Christian anti-Judaism eventually was crucial to what later became anti-Semitism.<ref>Peter Sch\xe4fer, https://books.google.com/books?id=8jIhYBwkO80C&pg=PA7  Judeophobia: Attitudes Toward the Jews in the Ancient World, Harvard University Press 1997 pp.6-7, p:7, pp.197ff.\u2019The only term I avoid is \u201canti-Judaism\u201d thus following those scholars who restrict it to early Christian expressions of hostility towards the Jews.\xec A. Roy Eckardt has asserted that the foundation of antisemitism and responsibility for the Holocaust lies ultimately in the New Testament.<ref name="Eckardt">A. Roy Eckhardt, https://books.google.com/books?id=LfhCAAAAIAAJ&q=A.+Roy+Eckhardt%2B+Elder+and+Younger+Brothers&dq=A.+Roy+Eckhardt%2B+Elder+and+Younger+Brothers&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y  Elder and Younger Brothers:The Encounter of Jews and Christians, Scribner New York, 1967 James Dunn (theologian) argues that the various New Testament expressions of anger and hurt by a minority puzzled by the refusal of a majority to accept their claims about Jesus the Jew  reflect inner tensions between Jewish communities not yet unified by Rabbinic Judaism, and a Christianity not yet detached from Judaism.<ref name ="Dunn"/>\n\nFactional agendas underpin the writing of the canonical texts, and the various NT documents are windows into the conflict and debates of that period.<ref>Abel Mordechai Bibliowicz,  https://books.google.com/books?id=CM9_dUMSvukC&pg=PT129 Jews and Gentiles in the Early Jesus Movement: An Unintended Journey,  Springer, 2013 p.93. According to Timothy Johnson, mutual slandering among competing sects was quite strong in the period when these works were composed.<ref>Lloyd Kim https://books.google.com/books?id=87RLAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA11 Polemic in the Book of Hebrews: Anti-Judaism, Anti-Semitism, Supersessionism?, Wipf and Stock Publishers, 2006 p.14. The  New Testament moreover is an ensemble of texts written over decades, and reflects the different milieux of composition.<ref>Guy Stroumsa, \u2018From anti-Judaism to antisemitism in Early Christianity,\u2019 p.5:I wish to recall that . . these texts were written in rather diverse milieus, and that therefore it is quite meaningless to speak about a single New Testament attitude.\u2019; https://books.google.com/books?id=X-yF4wPWF5EC&pg=PA16 p.16 \u2018The context and meaning of the rejection of the Jews in the Gospel of John, . .are vastly different from Chrysostom\u2019s anti-Jewish invective. We cannot speak of a single early Christian or Patristic attitude toward Jews and Judaism, or imply its existence. Both the relationship of Christianity to Judaism and the Christians\u2019 perceptions of Jews were totally different at the end of the fourth century than they had been three hundred years previously\u2019.\n\n\n\nA. Roy Eckardt, a pioneer in the field of Jewish-Christian relations,<ref>http://hgs.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/reprint/12/3/519.pdf In Memoriam: Professor A. Roy Eckardt Holocaust and Genocide Studies 1998 12(3):519 asserted that the foundation of antisemitism and responsibility for the Holocaust lies ultimately in the New Testament.<ref name="Eckardt"/> Eckardt insisted that Christian repentance must include a reexamination of basic theological attitudes toward Jews and the New Testament in order to deal effectively with antisemitism.\n\nAccording to Rabbi Michael J. Cook, Professor of Intertestamental and Early Christian Literature at the Hebrew Union College, there are ten themes in the New Testament that are the greatest sources of anxiety for Jews concerning Christian antisemitism:\n# The Jewish deicide - as such they are guilty of deicide\n# The tribulations of the Jewish people throughout history constitute Gods punishment of them for killing Jesus\n# Jesus originally Matthew 10, but when Rejection of Jesus, he abandoned them for gentiles instead\n# The Children of Israel were Gods original chosen people by virtue of an ancient Covenant (biblical), but by rejecting Jesus they forfeited their chosenness - and now, by virtue of a New Covenant (or "testament"), Supersessionism, the Church having become the "People of God."\n# The Jewish Bible (the so-called "Old Testament") repeatedly portrays the opaqueness and stubbornness of the Jewish people and their disloyalty to God.\n# The Jewish Bible contains Typology (theology) as the Messiah (or "Christ"), yet the Jews are blind to the meaning of their own Bible.\n# By the time of Ministry of Jesus, Judaism had ceased to be a living faith.\n# Judaisms essence is a restrictive and burdensome Legalism (theology).\n# Agape, while Judaism maintains a balance of justice, Divine retribution and love of peace.\n# Judaisms oppressiveness reflects the disposition of Jesus opponents called "Pharisees" (predecessors of the "rabbis"), who in their teachings and behavior were hypocrites (see Woes of the Pharisees).<ref>A. James Rudin, https://books.google.com/books?id=kW7gAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA89 Christians & Jews\u2014Faith to Faith: Tragic History, Promising Present, Fragile Future, Jewish Lights Publishing, 2013 p.89.\n\nCook believes that both contemporary Jews and contemporary Christians need to reexamine the history of early Christianity, and the Split of early Christianity and Judaism consisting of Jewish Christianity, to a separate religion often dependent on the tolerance of Rome while proselytizing among Gentiles loyal to the Roman empire, to understand how the story of Jesus came to be recast in an anti-Jewish form as the Gospels took their final form.\n\nSome scholars assert that critical verses in the New Testament have been used to incite prejudice and violence against Jewish people. Professor Lillian C. Freudmann, author of Antisemitism in the New Testament (University Press of America, 1994) has published a study of such verses and the effects that they have had in the Christian community throughout history. Similar studies have been made by both Christian and Jewish scholars, including, Professors Clark Williamsom (Christian Theological Seminary), Hyam Maccoby (The Leo Baeck Institute), Norman A. Beck (Texas Lutheran College),  and Michael Berenbaum (Georgetown University).\n\n\nThere are some verses in the New Testament that describe Jews in a positive way, attributing to them salvation or divinity love. In the story of the Crucifixion of Jesus, meanwhile, Jews prompt Jesus execution and say "His blood be on us, and on our children",  referred to as the blood curse. In the Gospel of John, Jesus calls certain Pharisees "children of the devil".\n\nAccording to the New Testament Gospels, Jesus, on his fateful entry into Jerusalem before Passover, was received by a great crowd of people. Jesus was arrested and Sanhedrin Trial of Jesus. After the trial, Jesus was handed over to Pontius Pilate, who duly tried him again and, at the urging of the people, had him death of Jesus.\n\nThe New Testament records that Jesus disciple Judas Iscariot, the Roman governor Pontius Pilate along with Roman forces and the leaders and people of Jerusalem were (to varying degrees) responsible for the death of Jesus.\n\n\nAccording to the Gospel of Mark, Jesus crucifixion was authorized by Roman empire authorities at the insistence of leading Jews (Judeans) from the Sanhedrin.\n\nPaul H. Jones writes:<ref name=Jones>Paul H. Jones,The Christian Formation of the Jew as Religious Other, in Encounter 67:2  2006 pp.161-197.\n\n\n\n\nMatthews Gospel is often evaluated as the most Jewish of the canonical gospels, and yet it is sometimes argued that it is anti-Judaic or anti-Semitic.<ref>Daniel J. Harrington, https://books.google.com/books?id=bNf13S3k2w0C&pg=PA20 The Gospel of Matthew, Liturgical Press 1991 p.20.\n\nMatthews Gospel has given readers the impression his hostility to Jews increases as his narrative progresses, until it culminates in chapter 23.<ref>Samuel Sandmel cited Harrison, The Gospel of Matthew, https://books.google.it/books?id=bNf13S3k2w0C&pg=PA20 p.20. In chapter 21, the Parable of the Workers in the Vineyard, which is strikingly similar to , is followed by the great "stone" text, an early Christological Exegesis of : "The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone".. The OT allusions appear to suggest that the author thought God would call to account Israels leaders for maltreating Christ, and that the covenant will pass to the Gentiles who follow Christ,<ref>Frank E.Eakin, https://books.google.it/books?id=zodV3hPCPtwC&pg=PA36 What Price Prejudice:Christian Antisemitism in America, Paulist Press 1998 p.36. a view that arose in intersectarian polemics in Judaism between the followers of Christ and the Jewish leadership.<ref>Rosemary Radford Ruether, https://books.google.it/books?id=gXk1qIxUrCIC&pg=PA61 Christianity and Social Systems: Historical Constructions and Ethical Challenges, Rowman & Littlefield, 2009  p.61. Then, in chapters 23 and 24, three successive hostile pericopes are recorded. First, a series of Woes of the Pharisees:\n\n\nCertain passages which speak of the destruction of Jerusalem have elements that are interpreted as indications of Matthews anti-Judaic attitudes. Jesus is said to have lamented over the capital: "Jerusalem, Jerusalem, the city that kills the prophets and stones those who are sent to it...See, your house is left to you, desolate" ().<ref>Frank S. Thielman, https://books.google.com/books?id=ACNZ_8YKTI4C&pg=PA102 Theology of the New Testament, Zondervan 2011 pp.102f. Again, Jesus is made to predict the demise of the Temple: "Truly I tell you, not one stone will be left here upon another; all will be thrown down" ().<ref name="Aageson" >James W. Aageson, https://books.google.com/books?id=SIPhCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA43 Windows on Early Christianity: Uncommon Stories, Striking Images, Critical Perspectives, Wipf and Stock Publishers, 2016  pp.43ff. Such visions of an end to the old Temple may be read as embodying the Supersessionism, according to which Christianity supersedes Judaism.<ref name="Aageson" />\n\nThe culmination of this rhetoric, and arguably the one verse that has caused more Jewish suffering than any other second Testament passage, is the uniquely Matthean attribution to the Jewish people: "His Jesuss blood be on us and on our children!" (). This so-called "blood guilt" text has been interpreted to mean that all Jews, of Jesus time and forever afterward, accept responsibility for the death of Jesus.\n\nShelly Matthews writes:\n\n\nDouglas Hare noted that the Gospel of Matthew avoids sociological explanations for persecution:\n\n\nThe term "Jews" in the Gospel of Matthew is applied to those who deny the Resurrection appearances of Jesus and believe that the Stolen body hypothesis.\n\n\nThe Gospel of John has long provided anti-Semites with grist for their mill.<ref>Larry R. Helyer, https://books.google.com/books?id=9ANeAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA324 The Witness of Jesus, Paul and John: An Exploration in Biblical Theology, InterVarsity Press, 2010 pp.324ff. There are 31 instances where the gospel uses the word Ioudaios|\u1f38\u03bf\u03c5\u03b4\u03b1\u1fd6\u03bf\u03b9, the Jews in a hostile sense,<ref>R. Alan Culpepper, Anti-Judaism in the Fourth Gospel as a Theological Problem for Christian Interpreters, in Reimund Bieringer, Didier Pollefeyt, Frederique Vandecasteele-Vanneuville  (eds.),https://books.google.com/books?id=GJKgs7fiH2cC&pg=PA64 Anti-Judaism and the Fourth Gospel, Publisher Westminster John Knox Press, 2001 pp.61-82, p.64. among the 63 uses <ref>Count from New King James Version as calculated by BibleGateway.com online version of the word in this gospel,<ref name ="BPVV">Reimund Bieringer, Didier Pollefeyt, Frederique Vandecasteele-Vanneuville, Wrestling with Johannine Anti-Judaism: A Hermeneutical Framework for the Analysis of the Current Debate, in Anti-Judaism and the Fourth Gospel, pp.3-41 https://books.google.com/books?id=GJKgs7fiH2cC&pg=PA15 p.15. and all Jewish groups are lumped together, with no distinctions made between them. The Sadducees, prominent elsewhere, disappear.<ref name ="K\xf6stenberger">Andreas J. K\xf6stenberger, https://books.google.com/books?id=Joglgt0gQL4C&pg=PA248 Encountering John: The Gospel in Historical, Literary, and Theological Perspective, Baker Academic, 2002 pp.248ff. The enemies of Jesus are described collectively as "the Jews", in contradistinction to the other evangelists, who do not generally <ref>An exception is Gospel of Matthew 27:25All the people (\u03c0\u1fb6\u03c2 \u1f41 \u03bb\u03b1\u1f78\u03c2) answered, "His blood is on us and on our children!" ascribe to "the Jews" en masse calls for the death of Jesus. In the other 3 texts, the plot to put him to death is always presented as coming from a small group of priests and rulers, the Sadducees.<ref name="BPVV" /> Johns gospel is thus the primary source of the image of "the Jews" acting collectively as the enemy of Jesus, which later became fixed in Christian minds.<ref>Gerd Theissen, Dagmar Winter, https://books.google.com/books?id=qB5ulgKx4OUC&pg=PA68 The Quest for the Plausible Jesus: The Question of Criteria, Westminster John Knox Press, 2002 p.68. Some still see the use of anti-Semitic to describe his outlook problematical, if not an indeed anachronistic: John was a Jew, writing of his hero, a Jew, namely, Jesus, who is said to have declared that a house divided against itself cannot stand.<ref>Gospel of Mark 3:24; Gospel of Matthew 12:25. John himself has Jesus tell Samaritan woman at the well that "salvation is from the Jews."<ref name="K\xf6stenberger" /><ref>Gospel of John, John 4:4-26, v.22.You Samaritans worship what you do not know; we worship what we do know, for salvation is from the Jews.(\u1f21 \u03c3\u03c9\u03c4\u03b7\u03c1\u03af\u03b1 \u1f10\u03ba \u03c4\u1ff6\u03bd \u1f38\u03bf\u03c5\u03b4\u03b1\u03af\u03c9\u03bd \u1f10\u03c3\u03c4\u03af\u03bd)\nFor example, in  Jesus moves around in Galilee but avoids Judea, because "the Jews" were looking for a chance to kill him. In  some said "he is a good man" whereas others said he deceives the people, but these were all "whispers", no one would speak publicly for "fear of the Jews". Jewish rejection is also recorded in , , , and .  says many did believe, but they kept it private, for fear the Pharisees would exclude them from the Synagogue. After the crucifixion,  has the Disciple (Christianity) hiding behind locked doors, "for fear of the Jews".\n\nIn several places Johns gospel also associates "the Jews" with darkness and with the devil. In John 8:37-39; Jesus says, speaking to a group of Pharisees:\n\n\nThough it has been claimed that the  modern consensus is that the term Ioudaioi/Jews in John refers exclusively to religious authorities,<ref>Kierspel, https://books.google.com/books?id=68f2cdlMtfMC&pg=PA14 p.13. the basis for this claim has been challenged and Johns use of the term Jews remains a complex and debated area of biblical scholarship.<ref>BPVV, https://books.google.com/books?id=GJKgs7fiH2cC&pg=PA15 pp.15-17<ref>R Alan Culpepper, https://books.google.com/books?id=ecsaUUzRdEUC&pg=PA294  The Gospel and Letters of John, Abington Press 1998 p.294:The Greek term hoi Ioudaioi can mean "the Jews," as it is usually translated, but it can also mean "the Judeans." In the Gospel of John the group designated by this term appears to be variously Judeans (as opposed to Galileans or Samaritans), the Judean leaders (where it is used interchangeably with "the Pharisees"), or-less frequently-Jews as opposed to Gentiles. The meaning of the term Ioudaioi, which is used 71 times in the Gospel, must therefore be determined by the context of each occurrence. There are places in John where the term can hardly mean "the Jews." . For example, although the crowd in Jerusalem at the Festival of Booths must have been predominantly Jewish, they still fear the Ioudaioi. By translating hoi Ioudaioi as "the Jews" in this context, the NRSV and other translations produce a reading that makes little sense. . Here it is clear that hoi Ioudaioi refers to a much more limited group opposed to Jesus, either certain Judean Jews or the religious authorities. The same difficulties appear elsewhere in the Gospel. New Testament scholar James Dunn (theologian) writes:\n\n\nReflecting the consensus that Johns use of the term refers strictly to Jewish religious authorities, some modern translations, such as Todays New International Version, remove the term "Jews" and replace it with more specific terms to avoid anti-Semitic connotations.<ref>Kierspel, https://books.google.com/books?id=68f2cdlMtfMC&pg=PA14 pp.13-14. For example, the Jesus Seminar translates this as "Judeans", i.e. residents of Judea, in contrast to residents of Galilee, a translation which has not found general acceptance.<ref>Frank Sherman and  with Sarah Henrich,Difficult Texts:Interpreting New Testament Images of Jews and Judaism, , in Darrell Jodock (ed.), https://books.google.com/books?id=thWFL5KgP24C&pg=PA205 Covenantal Conversations: Christians in Dialogue with Jews and Judaism , Fortress Press 2008 pp.76-90  p.205 n.13.\n\n\nSuccessive generations of Christians read in the Gospel of John the collective guilt of Jews, universally and in all generations, in the death of Christ. Johns use of the collective expression "the Jews" is likely explained by the historical circumstances in which and audience for which he wrote. With the Siege of Jerusalem (70), the Jewish priesthood, and thus the class of the Sadducees was massacred and thus ceased to exist, due to its role in the First Jewish-Roman War. As John wrote his Gospel after these events, for a gentile audience, he spoke generically of Jews, rather than specifying a group within Judaism that no longer existed and that would have been unfamiliar to his readers.<ref name=CatholiCity101>\n\n\nPaul writes in 1 Thessalonians 2:14-16 as follows:\n\n\nThe text appears somewhat anomalous compared to the general tone of thanksgiving, in that we have a diatribe against persecutors identified as Jews.<ref name="Downey" /> The text appears to flagrantly contradict what Paul writes in chapters 9 to 11 of his Epistle to the Romans. This has led several scholars to question its authenticity, and suggest that it is an interpolation.<ref>David Luckensmeyer,https://books.google.com/books?id=0KuT2qkhtGEC&pg=PA161 The Eschatology of First Thessalonians, Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, 2013 pp.16fff. According to Pieter Willem van der Horst, there is an instance of antisemitic statements in one of the Pauline epistles;<ref name=Pieter1> David Luckensmeyer maintains that it was not written with the intent to condemn all Jews, - Pauls letters reveal someone who lived his life within Judaism - but did at the same time have an anti-Semitic "effect".<ref>David Luckensmeyer. https://books.google.com/books?id=0KuT2qkhtGEC&pg=PA167  pp.167-171. F. F. Bruce called it an indiscriminate anti-Jewish polemic mirroring Graeco-Roman pagan attitudes to the Jews. Gene Green, Ernest Best,T. Holtz, Amy Downey variously argue that it resonates with Old Testament themes, plays on Jewish fears of being the "privileged people of God" and typical of an argumentative style shared by Greeks and Jews alike and thus, in Downeys words, exemplifying an intracultural clash between Paul the Jew and  Jewish leaders opposing the propagation of Gospel ideas in both Judea and Thessalonia.<ref name="Downey" >Amy Karen Downey,  https://books.google.com/books?id=15VMAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA61 Pauls Conundrum: Reconciling 1 Thessalonians 2:13-16 and Romans 9:1-5 in Light of His Calling and His Heritage, Wipf and Stock Publishers, 2011 pp.61ff,66-7.\n\n\nMost scholars  consider the Epistle to the Hebrews to have been written for Christians who were tempted to return to Judaism. Lillian Freudmann thinks that it in  trying to argue the superiority of Christianity to Judaism, it twisted Old Testament passages in a way that transmitted an anti-Torah antisemitism. John Gager reads it as a polemic against Judaism, not the Jewish people, and regards it as the most important anti-Judaising text of early Christianity. Samuel Sandmel asserts that rather than vilifying Judaism, or the Jews of that age, the Epistle to the Hebrews is an argument for the supersessionism notion that Christianity is the pinnacle of ancient Judaism. William L. Lane dismissed the idea that it contains an anti-Judaic polemic, its primary concern being simply to assert that the Old Testament prophecies had been fulfilled. Those who see in its discontinuities anti-Semitism are wrong William Hagner argued: there may be anti-Judaism, but no antagonism for Jews. While it promotes supersessionism  it venerates the Hebrew saints, for Donald Bloesch, and therefore what it is exhorting is the replacement of Jewish institutions, not Jews. For Timothy Johnson, Christianity had to struggle to survive amid a majority of sects that were not Messianic, and whatever slander there is, is to be understood as the rhetoric of a marginal group against the majority of Jews. Such rhetorical vehemence was common in antiquity in religious and philosophical disputes.<ref>Lloyd Kim https://books.google.com/books?id=87RLAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA11 Polemic in the Book of Hebrews: Anti-Judaism, Anti-Semitism, Supersessionism?, Wipf and Stock Publishers, 2006 pp.11-16.\n\n\nIn Revelation 2:9 and 3:9 reference is made to a synagogue of Satan (\u03c3\u03c5\u03bd\u03b1\u03b3\u03c9\u03b3\u03ae \u03c4\u03bf\u1fe6 \u03a3\u03b1\u03c4\u03b1\u03bd\u1fb6).  At Revelation 2:9 we have:\n<blockquote>I know your afflictions and your poverty--yet you are rich! I know about the slander of those who say they are Jews and are not, but are a synagogue of Satan.<ref>Revelation 2:9:\u039f\u1f36\u03b4\u03ac \u03c3\u03bf\u03c5 \u03c4\u1f74\u03bd \u03b8\u03bb\u1fd6\u03c8\u03b9\u03bd \u03ba\u03b1\u1f76 \u03c4\u1f74\u03bd \u03c0\u03c4\u03c9\u03c7\u03b5\u03af\u03b1\u03bd, \u1f00\u03bb\u03bb\u1f70 \u03c0\u03bb\u03bf\u03cd\u03c3\u03b9\u03bf\u03c2 \u03b5\u1f36, \u03ba\u03b1\u1f76 \u03c4\u1f74\u03bd \u03b2\u03bb\u03b1\u03c3\u03c6\u03b7\u03bc\u03af\u03b1\u03bd \u1f10\u03ba \u03c4\u1ff6\u03bd \u03bb\u03b5\u03b3\u03cc\u03bd\u03c4\u03c9\u03bd \u1f38\u03bf\u03c5\u03b4\u03b1\u03af\u03bf\u03c5\u03c2 \u03b5\u1f36\u03bd\u03b1\u03b9 \u1f11\u03b1\u03c5\u03c4\u03bf\u03cd\u03c2, \u03ba\u03b1\u1f76 \u03bf\u1f50\u03ba \u03b5\u1f30\u03c3\u03af\u03bd \u1f00\u03bb\u03bb\u1f70 \u03c3\u03c5\u03bd\u03b1\u03b3\u03c9\u03b3\u1f74 \u03c4\u03bf\u1fe6 \u03a3\u03b1\u03c4\u03b1\u03bd\u1fb6.</blockquote>\nAt 3:9 one reads:\n<blockquote> I will make those who are of the synagogue of Satan, who claim to be Jews though they are not, but are liars--I will make them come and fall down at your feet and acknowledge that I have loved you<ref>Revelations 3:9:\u1f30\u03b4\u03bf\u1f7a \u03b4\u03b9\u03b4\u1ff6  \u1f10\u03ba \u03c4\u1fc6\u03c2 \u03c3\u03c5\u03bd\u03b1\u03b3\u03c9\u03b3\u1fc6\u03c2 \u03c4\u03bf\u1fe6 \u03a3\u03b1\u03c4\u03b1\u03bd\u1fb6, \u03c4\u1ff6\u03bd \u03bb\u03b5\u03b3\u03cc\u03bd\u03c4\u03c9\u03bd \u1f11\u03b1\u03c5\u03c4\u03bf\u1f7a\u03c2  \u1f38\u03bf\u03c5\u03b4\u03b1\u03af\u03bf\u03c5\u03c2 \u03b5\u1f36\u03bd\u03b1\u03b9, \u03ba\u03b1\u1f76 \u03bf\u1f50\u03ba \u03b5\u1f30\u03c3\u1f76\u03bd \u1f00\u03bb\u03bb\u1f70 \u03c8\u03b5\u03cd\u03b4\u03bf\u03bd\u03c4\u03b1\u03b9\xb7 \u1f30\u03b4\u03bf\u1f7a \u03c0\u03bf\u03b9\u03ae\u03c3\u03c9 \u03b1\u1f50\u03c4\u03bf\u1f7a\u03c2  \u1f35\u03bd\u03b1 \u1f25\u03be\u03bf\u03c5\u03c3\u03b9\u03bd \u03ba\u03b1\u1f76 \u03c0\u03c1\u03bf\u03c3\u03ba\u03c5\u03bd\u03ae\u03c3\u03bf\u03c5\u03c3\u03b9\u03bd \u1f10\u03bd\u03ce\u03c0\u03b9\u03bf\u03bd \u03c4\u1ff6\u03bd \u03c0\u03bf\u03b4\u1ff6\u03bd \u03c3\u03bf\u03c5, \u03ba\u03b1\u1f76 \u03b3\u03bd\u1ff6\u03c3\u03b9\u03bd \u1f45\u03c4\u03b9 \u1f10\u03b3\u1f7c \u1f20\u03b3\u03ac\u03c0\u03b7\u03c3\u03ac \u03c3\u03b5.</blockquote>\n\nThere is no certainty about who are those claiming falsely  to be Jews:<ref>Bas Wilenga, https://books.google.com/books?id=S0npAyPMzu0C&pg=PA18  Revelation to John: Tuning Into Songs of Moses and the Lamb,   Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge(India), 2009  pp.17 (Smyrna) pp.27 ()Philadelphia) whether they are Jews hostile to Gentiles, Christian Jews persecuted by a Jewish majority or Gentiles feigning to be Jews.<ref name ="Koester">Craig Koester, https://books.google.com/books?id=31VmBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA271  Revelation: A New Translation with  Introduction and Commentary,   Yale University Press 2014 pp.2711ff.pp.274-276:\u2019Synagogue members at Smyrna presumably considered opposition to the church to be consistent with Israel\u2019s tradition since they thought that Jesuss followers had departed from the tradition by making elevated claims about Jesus. From John\u2019s perspective, however, their attempt to denounce Jesus followers-especially when this could lead to imprisonment and death-was incompatible with loyalty to Israels God. For John, those who denounce Christians thereby denounce the God to whom they bear witness, so he calls it blasphemia. Moreover, the Jews who made such denunciations joined forces with civic and provincial authorities-who worshiped other gods-in their efforts to have Christians arrested. For John, true Jews woiuld not have collaborated with idolators. Other interpretations are less viable. Some assume that the inauthentic Jews are Gentile Christians. First, some argue that these Christians keep Jewish customs and affiliate with the synagogue to avoid Roman persecution. . .Second, some interpreters hold that the so-called Jews are Christians like Jezebel and Nicolaitans, who might have claimed to be part of the Jewish tradition, even though they eat what has been sacrificed to idols..Other interpretations take the so-called Jews to be non-Christians.\nThe traditional interpretation upheld until recently by a majority of scholars took this to denote Jews hostile to Christians, and specifically to the Jewish communities of Smyrna (2:9) and Ala\u015fehir (3:9).<ref>Robert H. Mounce, https://books.google.com/books?id=lWhyCgAAQBAJ&pg=PT120  The Book of Revelation,  Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing,rev.ed. 1997 p.101.<ref>Adela Yarbro Collins,https://books.google.com/books?id=Rw9e2DfVxiEC&pg=PA85 Crisis and Catharsis: The Power of the Apocalypse,  Westminster John Knox Press, 1984 pp85ff.<ref>Steve Friesen, https://books.google.com/books?id=zHLZob88C44C&pg=PA134  \u2019Sarcasm in Revelations 2-3,\u2019 in David L. Barr (ed.),  https://books.google.com/books?id=zHLZob88C44C&pg=PA153 The Reality of Apocalypse: Rhetoric and Politics in the Book of Revelation, Society of Biblical Lit, 2006 pp.127-144 p.134.  In the Smyrna passage, according to Koester,  those claiming to be Jews probably bore in their traits the usual markers of kinship, circumcision, dietary restriction and Sabbath observance, but  are taken  to task for denouncing the Christian community to the Roman authorities to get them arrested.<ref name ="Koester" />\n\nThis has recently been questioned by Elaine Pagels, David Frankfurter, Heinrich Kraft and  John W. Marshall. Pagels, reviewing the literature, argues that the author of Revelations, John of Patmos, was himself a Jew devoted to Christ, saw himself as a Jew, not a Christian. Unlike the other evangelists who blame Jews for Christ\u2019s death, the author of Revelations, drawing on old patterns of late Jewish eschatology, assigns responsibility for his death to Romans and  says they are abetted by an internal enemy who feign to be God\u2019s people while acting as agents of Satan, a theme also present in the literature of the Qumran Dead Sea Scrolls. Pagels identifies most of  these internal enemies as converts to the Paul the Apostle Pauline Christianity prevailing among gentiles. Taken literally the passage at Revelations 3:9 would refer to Gentiles upstaging Jewish followers of Jesus, feigning to be more Jewish than Jews themselves. Paul Duff on the other hand  assumes they are Jews, like John himself, but Jews who are hostile to the Jesus movement. David Frankfurter has revived the old argument of Ferdinand Christian Baur by endorsing the view that in fact the members of Satans synagogue are mostly Gentiles, claiming Israels legacy while rebuffing religious practices that are obligatory for Jews. Even those who, like David Aune, consider that the phrase indicates Jews, not Gentiles, allow that the Books of Revelations is virtually devoid of traces of the polemics between Christians and Jews typical of those times. Pagels  concludes that the evidence weighs in favour of reading the synagogue of Satan as referring to gentile converts to the Pauline version of the Jesus movement, who denominate themselves as those of Christ/Christians, a terminology never used by John of Patmos.<ref>Elaine Pagels https://books.google.com/books?id=_1knBwAAQBAJ&pg=PA9  \u2018The Social History of Satan:John of Patmos and Ignatius of Antioch:Contrasting Visions of \u201cGod\u2019s People\u201d,\u2019 in Kirsten Stirling, Martine Hennard Dutheil de la Roch\xe8re   (eds.) After Satan: Essays in Honour of Neil Forsyth,  Cambridge Scholars Publishing, 2010 pp.7-28 pp.9ff.pp.14ff.<ref>Paul Duff, https://books.google.com/books?id=zHLZob88C44C&pg=PA153 The \u2018Synagogue of Satan\u2019: Crisis Mongering and the Apocalypse of John,\u2019 in David L. Barr (ed.), The Reality of Apocalypse: Rhetoric and Politics in the Book of Revelation, Society of Biblical Lit, 2006 pp.147-168 p.153.<ref>Elaine Pagels, https://books.google.com/books?id=-33IVLAc6dkC&pg=PT57 Revelations: Visions, Prophecy, and Politics in the Book of Revelation,  Penguin, 2012 pp.64-65:\u2019By the time John of Patmos traveled to Asia Minor, then, he found many followers of Paul who apparently assumed that even  groups consisting largely of Gentile converts had now, in effect, become Jews. No wonder, then, that when John heard of such people who \u201csay they are Jews, and are not, but are lying,\u201d he found their claims outrageous. ..John reassures  those who really are  Jews that Jesus has promised that when he comes back. Distressed as he was by such people, John could hardly have imagined what he might have seen as the greatest identity theft of all time: that eventually Gentile believers not only would call themselves Israel but would claim to be the sole rightful heirs to the legacy of God\u2019s chosen people.\u2019\n\nIt has been argued that the idea of a Jewish Antichrist developed from these verses.<ref>Walter Laqueur , https://books.google.com/books?id=8GHc5xtXD5UC&pg=PA47 "The Changing Face of Anti-Semitism: From Ancient Times to the Present Day, " Oxford University Press, 2006  pp.46\u201347<ref name="Timesofcrisis">Moshe Lazar, https://books.google.com/books?id=bzUTCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA45   \u2018The Lamb and the Scapegoat: The Dehumanization of Jews in Medieval Propaganda,\u2019 in  Sander Gilman,  Steven T. Katz (eds.) "Anti-Semitism in Times of Crisis, " New York University Press  1991 pp.38-79 pp.45-46\n\n\nIn the decree Nostra aetate in 1965, Pope Paul VI declared that \n<blockquote>"True, the Jewish authorities and those who followed their lead pressed for the death of Christ; still, what happened in His passion cannot be charged against all the Jews, without distinction, then alive, nor against the Jews of today. Although the Church is the new people of God, the Jews should not be presented as rejected or accursed by God, as if this followed from the Holy Scriptures."<ref>Jeremy Cohen, https://books.google.com/books?id=83FjAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA168 Christ Killers: the Jews and the Passion from the Bible to the Big Screen, Oxford University Press 2007 p.168.<ref>David Cymet,https://books.google.com/books?id=Pp7DZigCaDcC&pg=PA449 History Vs. Apologetics: The Holocaust, the Third Reich, and the Catholic Church, Lexington Books 2010 p.449.</blockquote>\n\nNorman Beck, professor of theology and classical languages at Texas Lutheran University, has proposed that Christian lectionary remove what he calls "\u2026 the specific texts identified as most problematic \u2026". Beck identifies what he deems to be offensive passages in the New Testament and indicates the instances in which these texts or portions thereof are included in major lectionary series.\n\nDaniel Goldhagen, former Associate Professor of Political Science at Harvard University, also suggested in his book A Moral Reckoning that the Roman Catholic Church should change its doctrine and the accepted Biblical canon to excise statements he labels as antisemitic,- he counts some 450 such passages in the Synoptic Gospels and Acts of the Apostles alone<ref>Lars Kierspel, \nhttps://books.google.com/books?id=68f2cdlMtfMC&pg=PA7 The Jews and the World in the Fourth Gospel: Parallelism, Function, and Context, :de:Mohr Siebeck Verlag 2006 p.5 citing D. Goldhagen,A Moral Reckoning, pp.263-265.-to indicate that "The Jews way to God is as legitimate as the Christian way".<ref name="Shoah">\n\n\n* Anti-Judaism in early Christianity\n* Christian\u2013Jewish reconciliation\n* Christianity and Judaism\n* Origins of Christianity\n\n\n* Freudmann, Lillian C. Antisemitism in the New Testament, University Press of America (1994); \n* Kee, Howard Clark and Borowsky, Irvin J., Removing the Anti-Judaism from the New Testament, American Interfaith Institute, Row(id=38424, title=u'Bikram Yoga', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\nBikram Yoga is a system of yoga that Bikram Choudhury synthesized from traditional hatha yoga techniques and popularized beginning in the early 1970s.<ref>http://wiki4yoga.blogspot.com/2014/03/corporate-registration-for-bikram.html Corporate registration for "Bikram Choudhury Yoga, Inc." Number: C2288343<ref name=Forbes> All Bikram Yoga Beginning Series classes run for 90 minutes and consist of the same series of 26 postures, including two breathing exercises. Bikram Yoga is a hot yoga style, and is ideally practiced in a room heated to  with a humidity of 40%.<ref name="Bikram Yoga Basic"> All official Bikram classes are taught by Bikram-certified teachers, who have completed nine weeks of training endorsed by Choudhury. Bikram-certified teachers are taught a standardized dialogue to run the class, but are encouraged to develop their teaching skills the longer they teach. This results in varying deliveries and distinct teaching styles.<ref name="Bikram Yoga Basic"/>\nFile:Bikram teaching.jpg|thumb|Bikram Choudhury leading a class, for Bikram yoga, at the L.A. Convention Center in 2003.\n\n\nBikram Choudhury, founder of the Bikram Yoga system, is also the founder of the Yoga College of India. Born in Calcutta in 1944, Choudhury began practicing yoga at age four. He stated that he practiced yoga 4\u20136 hours every day. At the age of thirteen, he asserts that he won the National India Yoga Championship and was undefeated for the following three years and retired as the undisputed All-India National Yoga Champion.\n . \n\nChoudhury later devised the 26 postures sequence and founded Bikrams Yoga College of India. He has also written books and sings.\n\nAs of 2006, he had 1,650 yoga studios around the world.\n\n\nA 2015 review found that one randomized controlled clinical trial has been conducted, using 21 healthy subjects with a mean age of 27; the study was too small to draw generalizations from but the people in the study arm had mildly improved strength and flexibility.\n\nA 2013 review of adverse effects from yoga found that Pranayama and Bikram were the most commonly cited styles, and found harm arising mostly in instructors who practiced intensely over a long period of time and who used advanced positions like handstands; in Bikram most of the adverse events arose from the heat and included hyponatriaemia due to excessive water drinking and sweating.\n\n\n\n\n\nOne controversial component of Bikram Yoga pertains to the prevalence of Yoga Asana Championships, regionally and nationally. While practitioners of other forms of yoga maintain that competition contradicts the idea of peace and unity, Choudhury contends, "Competition is the foundation for all democratic societies. For without Competition, there is no democracy."<ref>http://www.bikramyoga.com Official website\n\nIn India, where yoga originated, yoga competitions have been around for over a century.\n\n\n\nChoudhury has claimed that Bikram Yoga is under copyright and that it could not be taught or presented by anyone whom he had not authorized. Choudhury began making those claims in 2011. In 2011 Choudhury started a lawsuit against Yoga to the People, a competing yoga studio founded by a former student of Choudhurys and with a location near one of the Bikram Yoga studios in New York. Choudhury lost at first instance, and appealed the decision, with the Court of Appeal dismissing his copyright claim over yoga poses in Bikram Yoga.\n\nAs a result of that lawsuit, the United States Copyright Office issued a clarification that yoga postures (asanas) could not be copyrighted in the way claimed by Choudhury, and that Yoga to the People and others could continue to freely teach these exercises.\n\n\nHBOs Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel aired a segment about Choudhury in which they showed and spoke to people about his infamous and grueling teacher training programs. His behavior includes sleep deprivation, shouting, name-calling, and ridiculing over participants weight, size or ability.\n\nSome quotes from their interview with him:\n\nOn Bikram Yoga and Choudhury\u2019s methods:\n\nBikram Choudhury: \u201cThis yoga worse than cocaine. Because you can get rid of cocaine, but once you used to this yoga, you can\u2019t stop. Because nothing in this world makes you feel better than this yoga.\u201d\n\nBikram Choudhury: \u201cI try to kill them. They don\u2019t die. I own\u2013 I torture them.\u201d\nHBO\u2019s Andrea Kremer:  \u201cAnd you have to do that? You have to torture them?\u201d\nBikram Choudhury: \u201cI love it.\u201d\n\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cWhat are some of the rules that you have?\u201d\nBikram Choudhury: \u201cNumber one: You have to forget who you are.\u201d\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cYou\u2019ve even said something along the lines of, \u2018I implant my mind in your brain.\u2019\u201d\nBikram Choudhury: \u201cYes. My way or highway. You don\u2019t like it? Get the fuck out of here.\u201d\n\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cYou can be pretty harsh. You never have any regrets about any of the things that you say?\u201d\nBikram Choudhury: \u201cOf course not. Why should I? I have to yell, scream, shout. \u2018You fat ass. What the fuck\u2019s wrong with you? What\u2019s wrong with you? You don\u2019t listen to me. You dumb\u2013 you dumb fuck.\u2019 Because she doesn\u2019t listen.\u201d\n\nOn Bikram Yoga\u2019s near-miraculous powers:\n\nBikram Choudhury: \u201cI cure Parkinson\u2019s disease, AIDS, cancer. Doctor knows very little about human body.\u201d\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cYou know more than doctors?\u201d\nBikram Choudhury: \u201cMillion times, billion times. I teach doctors. I don\u2019t go to doctors. Every doctor in the world, they come to me.\u201d\n\n\nTwo lawsuits accusing Choudhury of rape were filed in May 2013, in which a Jane Doe alleges sexual battery, false imprisonment, discrimination, harassment, and other counts in addition to the rape allegation. It describes a cult-like atmosphere where Choudhurys followers help him find young women to assault. "Other persons in defendant Bikram Choudhurys inner circle, were aware of defendant Bikram Choudhurys pattern and practice of causing, inducing or persuading young women to enroll in teacher training classes to become yoga instructors only so he can sexually assault and/or rape them," the lawsuit claims.\n\nThe suits paint a cult-like atmosphere at the training camps. Trainees were allegedly told that Choudhury is on the same level as Jesus Christ or Gautama Buddha, that Bikram yoga can cure cancer and that practitioners will be able to live to 100 years old. Trainees were bullied and humiliated as well as praised, the suits say, and Choudhury allegedly gave lectures in which he disparaged gays, Americans and made ethnic slurs. Jane Doe 2 claims that Choudhury recruits volunteers from overseas who are "so in fear of defendant Bikram Choudhurys wrath that they will travel to the US and risk violating immigration laws in order to serve him. Once in the US these volunteers work for little or zero pay. "Their duties include grooming him, massaging him, making his tea, bringing him food and being forced to submit to sexual assaults and rapes against their will," the suit alleges.\n\nMinakshi "Micki"Jafa-Bodden served as Head of Legal and International Affairs from Spring 2011 to March 13, 2013 when she claims she was "abruptly and unlawfully terminated" according to the court documents filed on July 12, 2013 in the Superior Court of California, Los Angeles. But perhaps the more serious matters lie within the 2 years that Jafa-Bodden worked closely with Choudhury, during which she claims she was victim and witness to Choudhurys "severe, ongoing, pervasive and offensive conduct" especially to women, as well as homosexuals, African Americans and basically every other minority. The complaint is the fourth sex-based discrimination/sexual harassment/rape related suit filed this year against Choudhury.\n\nBikram teacher Sarah Baughn filed a sexual harassment suit in March (just before Jafa-Bodden was fired), and two other unnamed women filed similar suits accusing Choudhury of sexual harassment, intimidation and rape in May.  Shea Law Offices and Shegerian & Associates, the attorneys representing Baughn, now represent a total of six women claiming Bikram sexually assaulted and/or raped them.\n\nIn April 2015, the accusations raised larger questions in the yoga community, including an article by the Washington Post "asking whether its wise to put so much faith in a guru".\n\nAugust 18, 2015, Petra Starke who was his attorney, President and CEO from 3/2013 to 1/2015 filed a complaint in the Superior Court of California, County of Los Angeles (A6037-90064). This complaint alleged nine issues including breach of contract, wrongful termination and failure to prevent discrimination and harassment.\n\nOctober 25, 2016 HBOs Real Sports with Bryant Gumbel airs an interview with Choudhury at one of his training programs in India. Correspondent Andrea Kremer also interviews three women who accuse him of raping them.\n\nQuotes from their interviews:\n\nJill Lawler: \u201cI felt so disgusting, but I just did what he told me to do, which was basically, like, manually jerk him off.  I hated doing it.  But I felt like I owed him, you know? I felt like I owed him for, like, my life.\u201d\n\nJill Lawler: \u201cHe hurt me, he assaulted me.\u201d\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cBikram forced you to have sex?\u201d\nJill Lawler: \u201cYeah.\u201d\n\nAndrea Kremer:  \u201cWhat do you think made you vulnerable to him?\u201d\nJill Lawler: \u201cLike, he was my guru. He wa\u2013 I can\u2019t even explain. Like, I really, really loved him. You know? I really, really did.\u201d\nMaggie Genthner: \u201cHe pulled me on the bed.  I\u2019m, like, screaming like, \u2018No. Stop.  Don\u2019t do this.  Please don\u2019t do this.\u2019  And he starts calling me an idiot, just over and over again. And then he penetrates me and I scream, \u2018You\u2019re hurting me.  You\u2019re hurting me.\u2019  I screamed it. And he replies, \u2018It\u2019s supposed to hurt.\u2019 All of a sudden, like, the veil lifts, the veil of who I think this person is.\u201d\n\nSarah Baughn: \u201cI wanted to kill myself. I tried several times to kill myself.\u201d\n\nSarah Baughn:  \u201cHe was in charge of all of these people, all of whom just sat and listened and laughed and applauded and regarded him as yoga god. People stand up for this person really no matter what.\u201d\n\n\nThe following are the 26 postures of Bikram Yoga. These are taught in the Beginning Bikram Yoga Class. The sequence is taught by people who have been trained and certified by Bikram Choudhury.\n{| class="wikitable"\n!#\n!Sanskrit\n!English\n!Benefits claimed\n|-\n|1\n|\u092a\u094d\u0930\u093e\u0923\u093e\u092f\u093e\u092e\nPranayama|Pr\u0101\u1e47\u0101y\u0101ma\n|Standing Deep Breathing (lit. Breath Extension)File:Bpose1.jpg|center\n|May help prevent respiratory problems\n|-\n|2\n|\u0905\u0930\u094d\u0927\u091a\u0928\u094d\u0926\u094d\u0930\u093e\u0938\u0928 with \u092a\u093e\u0926\u0939\u0938\u094d\u0924\u093e\u0938\u0928\nArdha Candrasana|Ardhacandr\u0101sana with  Padahastasana|P\u0101dahast\u0101sana\n|Half Moon Pose with Hands To Feet PoseFile:Bpose2.jpg|center\n|Strengthens muscles in bodys core along with improving flexibility of the spine\n|-\n|3\n|\u0909\u0924\u094d\u0915\u091f\u093e\u0938\u0928\nUtkatasana|Utka\u1e6d\u0101sana\n|Awkward PoseFile:Bpose3.jpg|center\n|Helps tone and shape legs while it may relieve arthritis in the legs\n|-\n|4\n|\u0917\u0930\u0941\u0921\u093e\u0938\u0928\nGarudasana|Garu\u1e0d\u0101sana\n|Eagle PoseFile:Bpose4.jpg|center\n|Opens up the 14 largest joints and helps fresh blood move through the reproductive system\n|-\n|5\n|\u0926\u0923\u094d\u0921\u093e\u092f\u092e\u0928 \u091c\u093e\u0928\u0941\u0936\u0940\u0930\u094d\u0937\u093e\u0938\u0928\nDa\u1e47\u1e0d\u0101yamana Janusirsasana|J\u0101nu\u015b\u012br\u1e63\u0101sana\n|Standing Head To Knee PoseFile:Bpose5.jpg|center\n|Improves the sciatic nerves flexibility and may strengthen hamstrings plus other leg muscles\n|-\n|6\n|\u0926\u0923\u094d\u0921\u093e\u092f\u092e\u0928 \u0927\u0928\u0941\u0930\u093e\u0938\u0928\nDa\u1e47\u1e0d\u0101yamana Dhanurasana|Dhanur\u0101sana\n|Standing Bow PoseFile:Bpose6.jpg|center\n|Helps develop balance while potentially firming upper thighs and the abdominal wall\n|-\n|7\n|\u0924\u0941\u0932\u093e\u0926\u0923\u094d\u0921\u093e\u0938\u0928\nTul\u0101da\u1e47\u1e0d\u0101sana\n|Balancing Stick PoseFile:Bpose7.jpg|center\n|Helps send blood to the heart, cleansing the arteries and veins\n|-\n|8\n|\u0926\u0923\u094d\u0921\u093e\u092f\u092e\u0928 \u0935\u093f\u092d\u0915\u094d\u0924\u092a\u093e\u0926 \u092a\u0936\u094d\u091a\u093f\u092e\u094b\u0924\u094d\u0924\u093e\u0928\u093e\u0938\u0928\nDa\u1e47\u1e0d\u0101yamana Vibhaktap\u0101da Paschimottanasana|Pa\u015bcimott\u0101n\u0101sana\n|Standing Separate Leg Stretching PoseFile:Bpose8.jpg|center\n|Helps stretch and strengthen sciatic nerves and tendons in the legs\n|-\n|9\n|\u0924\u094d\u0930\u093f\u0915\u094b\u0923\u093e\u0938\u0928\nTrikonasana|Triko\u1e47\u0101sana\n|Triangle PoseFile:Bpose9.jpg|center\n|May help alleviate lower back pain and crooked spines while improving muscles and internal organs\n|-\n|10\n|\u0926\u0923\u094d\u0921\u093e\u092f\u092e\u0928 \u0935\u093f\u092d\u0915\u094d\u0924\u092a\u093e\u0926 \u091c\u093e\u0928\u0941\u0936\u0940\u0930\u094d\u0937\u093e\u0938\u0928\nDa\u1e47\u1e0d\u0101yamana Vibhaktap\u0101da Janusirsasana|J\u0101nu\u015b\u012br\u1e63\u0101sana\n|Standing Separate Leg Head To Knee PoseFile:Bpose11.jpg|center\n|May help regulate metabolism and immune system while trimming the lower body\n|-\n|11\n|\u0924\u093e\u0921\u093e\u0938\u0928\nTadasana|T\u0101\u1e0d\u0101sana\n|Tree PoseFile:Bpose10.jpg|center\n|Helps improve posture, balance and flexibility while strengthening oblique muscles\n|-\n|12\n|\u092a\u093e\u0926\u093e\u0919\u094d\u0917\u0941\u0937\u094d\u0920\u093e\u0938\u0928\nP\u0101d\u0101\u1e45gu\u1e63\u1e6dh\u0101sana\n|Toe Stand PoseFile:Bpose12.jpg|center\n|Helps strengthen knees, ankles, and feet while potentially reducing hemorrhoid problems\n|-\n|13\n|\u0936\u0935\u093e\u0938\u0928\nSavasana|\u015aav\u0101sana\n|Corpse PoseFile:Bpose13.jpg|center\n|Helps circulation and the blood flows throughout the body to create internal cleansing\n|-\n|14\n|\u092a\u0935\u0928\u092e\u0941\u0915\u094d\u0924\u093e\u0938\u0928\nPavanamuktasana|Pavanamukt\u0101sana\n|Wind Removing PoseFile:Bpose14.jpg|center\n|Compresses the digestive system and helps strengthen the arms, abdomen and thighs while improving hip flexibility\n|-\n|15\n|\u092a\u093e\u0926\u0939\u0938\u094d\u0924\u093e\u0938\u0928\nPadahastasana|P\u0101dahast\u0101sana\n|SitupFile:Bpose15.jpg|center\n|Helps increase flexibility to stretch the spine and improves circulation of the legs by working the muscles\n|-\n|16\n|\u092d\u0941\u091c\u0919\u094d\u0917\u093e\u0938\u0928\nBhujangasana|Bhuja\u1e45g\u0101sana\n|Cobra PoseFile:Bpose16.jpg|center\n|Helps strengthen the spine and may relieve pain from scoliosis, arthritis and menstrual disorders while potentially improving the digestive system\n|-\n|17\n|\u0936\u0932\u092d\u093e\u0938\u0928\nSalabhasana|\u015aalabh\u0101sana\n|Locust PoseFile:Bpose17.jpg|center\n|Similar benefits as Cobra\nHelps strengthen the upper spine and legs\n|-\n|18\n|\u092a\u0942\u0930\u094d\u0923\u0936\u0932\u092d\u093e\u0938\u0928\nP\u016br\u1e47a\u015balabh\u0101sana\n|Full Locust PoseFile:Bpose18.jpg|center\n|May relieve pain from scoliosis and slipped discs while strengthening the middle spine and increasing elasticity of the rib cage\n|-\n|19\n|\u0927\u0928\u0941\u0930\u093e\u0938\u0928\nDhanurasana|Dhanur\u0101sana\n|Bow PoseFile:Bpose19.jpg|center\n|Helps increase circulation and strength of the spine while revitalizing the spinal nerves and opening up the rib cage to expand lungs\n|-\n|20\n|\u0938\u0941\u092a\u094d\u0924\u0935\u091c\u094d\u0930\u093e\u0938\u0928\nVajrasana (yoga)|Suptavajr\u0101sana\n|Fixed Firm Pose (lit. Reclining Thunderbolt Pose)File:Bpose20.jpg|center\n|Helps improve strength and flexibility of the lower spine, knees, hips and ankle joints while increasing circulation that may relieve pain\n|-\n|21\n|\u0905\u0930\u094d\u0927\u0915\u0942\u0930\u094d\u092e\u093e\u0938\u0928\nKurmasana|Ardhak\u016brm\u0101sana\n|Half Tortoise PoseFile:Bpose21.jpg|center\n|Helps increase blood flow to the brain and stretches the lower part of the lungs while relieving tension in the neck and shoulders\n|-\n|22\n|\u0909\u0937\u094d\u091f\u094d\u0930\u093e\u0938\u0928\nUstrasana|U\u1e63\u1e6dr\u0101sana\n|Camel PoseFile:Bpose22.jpg|center\n|Stimulates the nervous system and improves flexibility of the spine and neck while stretching the abdominal organs and throat\n|-\n|23\n|\u0936\u0938\u093e\u0902\u0917\u093e\u0938\u0928\u093e\nSasangasana|\u015aas\u0101\u1e41g\u0101san\u0101\n|Rabbit PoseFile:Bpose23.jpg|center\n|Increases elasticity of the spine and back muscles while potentially helping to alleviate colds or sinus problems and may relieve tension near the neck and shoulders\n|-\n|24\n|\u091c\u093e\u0928\u0941\u0936\u0940\u0930\u094d\u0937\u093e\u0938\u0928 with \u092a\u0936\u094d\u091a\u093f\u092e\u094b\u0924\u094d\u0924\u093e\u0928\u093e\u0938\u0928\nJanusirsasana|J\u0101nu\u015b\u012br\u1e63\u0101sana with Paschimottanasana|Pa\u015bcimott\u0101n\u0101sana\n|Head To Knee Pose with Back Stretching PoseFile:Bpose24.jpg|center\n|May improve digestion and circulation in the bowels while helping the immune system\n|-\n|25\n|\u0905\u0930\u094d\u0927\u092e\u0924\u094d\u0938\u094d\u092f\u0947\u0928\u094d\u0926\u094d\u0930\u093e\u0938\u0928\nArdha Matsyendr\u0101sana\n|Spine Twisting Pose (lit. Half Lord of the Fishes Pose)File:Bpose25.jpg|center\n|Helps improve elasticity of the spine and increases circulation in the spinal nerves while relieving lower back pain\n|-\n|26\n|\u0915\u092a\u093e\u0932\u092d\u093e\u0924\u093f\nKap\u0101labh\u0101ti\n|Blowing In Firm Pose (lit. Skull Illuminating)File:Bpose26.jpg|center\n|Strengthens the abdominal organs while increasing the elasticity of the lungs and helping improve digestion and circulation\n|\n\n\n\n\n\n\nCategory:Yoga
