Row(id=314174, title=u'Kajukenbo', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n Territory of Hawaii\n| creator      = Adriano Emperado, Peter Young Yil Choo, Joe Holck, Frank Ordonez, George Chang\n| parenthood   = Kara-Ho Kempo, Danzan-ryu, Judo, Shotokan Karate, Tang Soo Do, Chuan Fa, Boxing, Eskrima<ref name="auto"/>\n| famous_pract = John Hackleman, Sage Northcutt, David Betlewski, Chuck Liddell\n| olympic      = No\n| website      =\n\nKajukenbo (Japanese language: \u30ab\u30b8\u30e5\u30b1\u30f3\u30dc Kajukenbo) is a hybrid martial arts from Hawaii. The name Kajukenbo is a portmanteau of the various arts from which its style is derived: KA for Karate, JU for Judo and Jujutsu, KEN for Kenpo and BO for Boxing.<ref name="auto"/><ref name="Emperado">\n\nIt was developed in the late 1940s and founded in 1947 in the Palama Settlement of Oahu, Hawaii. The art was created through the cooperative efforts of five martial artists, each with a different specialty: Peter Choo, Frank Ordonez, Joe Holck, George Chang and Adriano Emperado.<ref name="emperado">\n\nKajukenbo training incorporates a blend of Strike (attack), kicking, throwing, takedown (grappling), joint locks and weapon disarmament.<ref name="auto">\n\nToday, Kajukenbo is practiced all over the world in many different branches. In contrast to many traditional martial arts, students are not required to mimic their teacher, but are encouraged to develop their own "expression" of the art.\n\n\n"Through this fist style one gains long life and happiness."<ref name="Usadojo">\n\n\nKajukenbo was founded in 1947 in the Palama Settlement on Oahu, Hawaii. In the late 1940s, the Palama Settlement was a violent area. Due to this environment, five martial artists from varying backgrounds came together with the goal of developing an art that would be practical and effective on the street. These founders sought to develop one style that would complement each of their individual styles and yet allow for effective fighting at a greater variety of ranges and speeds.\n\nThe five founding members of Kajukenbo were:<ref name="Emperado"/>\n* Adriano Directo Emperado \u2014 Kara-Ho Kempo and Eskrima\n* Joseph Holck \u2014 Judo\n* Peter Young Yil Choo \u2014 Tang Soo Do, Shotokan Karate and Boxing\n* Frank F. Ordonez \u2014 Danzan-ry\u016b\n* George Chang \u2014 Chuan Fa\n\nIn its conception, the founders followed a simple rule, if a technique worked consistently on the street (or against one another), then it stayed in the system, if it did not, it was discarded.  This allowed the style to maintain its self-defense focus, while covering limitations found within each of their traditional arts.\n\n\n*  Korean karate / Tang Soo Do\n*  Judo\n*  Kara-Ho Kempo\n*  Siu Lum Pai Gung Fu / Chinese Boxing\n*  Danzan-ry\u016b\n*  Chuan Fa\n*  Eskrima\n\n\nFile:Kajukenbo-crest2.png|thumb|150px|right\nShortly after its conception, the Korean War broke out, and with it Joe Holck, Peter Choo, Frank Ordonez, and Clarence Chang left Hawaii on active military service, leaving only Adriano Emperado to continue teaching the system.\n\nEmperado and his brother Joe introduced Kajukenbo to the public by opening the Palama Settlement School in 1950. They called the school the Kajukenbo Self Defense Institute (K.S.D.I.). The training there was notoriously brutal. Their goal was to be invincible on the street, thus the students sparred with full contact. Emperado had a motto, "The workout isnt over until I see blood on the floor". He also said "the best teacher is pain". His philosophy was that if someone was afraid of pain they would be defeated the first time they were hit. Those who remained developed into tough fighters with a reputation for employing their art in street fights with little provocation.\n\nIn 1959,  Emperado continued to add more Kung Fu into Kajukenbo, shifting the art to a more fluid combination of hard and soft techniques. Since then, Kajukenbo has proved to be an improvement-based, continuously evolving and open form. John Leoning, also helped bring out the "bo" of Kajukenbo by pointing out that there should be no wasted motion.\n\nThe art slowly began to grow in popularity, and soon Emperado had 12 Kajukenbo schools in Hawaii, making it the second largest string of schools at the time. Joe Halbuna, Charles Gaylord, Tony Ramos and Aleju Reyes, who all earned a black belt from Emperado, brought Kajukenbo to the U.S. mainland in 1960. They each opened Kajukenbo schools in California. In 1969, Tony Ramos trained with and exchanged ideas and methods with Bruce Lee. Tonys version of Kajukenbo became known as the "Ramos Method" and is kept alive by numerous instructors.\n\nIn a 1991 interview with Black Belt Magazine, Emperado was asked who some of the Kajukenbo tournament stars were and said  According to Chuck Norris, in his book Against All Odds: My Story,  he won the middleweight title in 1967, at the Long Beach Internationals; then defeated Carlos Bunda who had won the lightweight title.\n\n\n\nKajukenbo continues to evolve with each generation and maintains its primary focus on realism and practicality. There are usually martial arts schools that will change along with time to fit into the days society. It is generally thought that "unfair" moves, such as strikes to the eyes or groin, are perfectly acceptable, as is whatever else the practitioner feels is necessary to get home that day.\n\nTraining workouts emphasize cardio conditioning and functional strength. While individual schools may show variation, it would not be unusual to train with sandbags or boxing gloves. There are core self-defense techniques at the heart of Kajukenbo and Kajukenbo schools eschew impractical and flashy moves. Most kajukenbo curricula feature counter-attacks to punches, kicks, grabs, as well as using knives, sticks and guns to counter back. While this base of common knowledge will keep schools styles similar, there is plenty of room for variation. This openness tends to encourage schools to incorporate other arts into their practice.  The primary concentration of all Kajukenbo schools remains real world self-defense, because protecting ones self in a street-fighting situation is primary.\n\nInnovation is what Kajukenbo represents.  In each generation and legacies that are passed on from teacher to students; there are changes that are inevitable.  Kokoro Healing and Empowerment is a concept derived from the Kajukenbo Martial Arts.  Sigung Donna Ramos-Burns has taken Kajukenbo and has incorporated Yoga/Pilates and Meditation to this fine art.  Targeted to women, she has helped many realize their empowerment through this program.  She was recognized by the State of California as an Innovative Finalist 2.0, a reward that recognizes healthier lifestyle living by exercising outdoors.  She continues to teach this to the Marin City community and does "Empowering" workshops in Universities throughout California.<ref>http://www.hphpbayarea.org/program/kokoro-healing-empowerment-program-0\n\n\n{| class="wikitable" style="float:right; text-align:center;"\n|+Traditional Belt Colors\n| | White ||  File:Judo white belt.svg\n|-\n| | Yellow ||  File:Judo yellow belt.svg\n|-\n| | Orange || File:Judo orange belt.svg\n|-\n| | Purple || File:Judo purple belt.svg\n|-\n| | Blue ||  File:Judo blue belt.svg\n|-\n| | Green|| File:Judo green belt.svg\n|-\n| | Brown ||  File:Judo brown belt.svg\n|-\n| | Black || File:Judo black belt.svg\n|\nRanking hierarchies vary widely from school to school.\n\nTraditional Japanese martial art ranking is often followed.  One common belt order is as follows: white, yellow, orange, purple, blue, green, brown, black. followed by the other various degrees of black belt. The schools have second and third stripe belts that feature a white for second or black for third stripe running down the center of the belt.\n\nBlack belt rankings and titles can also vary, with most schools adopting either Chinese or Japanese titles.\n\n\n\n\nKenpo "Adriano Emperado Method" or "Traditional Hard Style".\n\n\nThe original style of Tum Pai might have been put together by Adriano D. Emperado, Al Dacascos and Al Dela Cruz in the early 60s to create an advanced style for the Kajukenbo system. In the mid-60s the developments that made up Tum Pai became incorporated into what was called "Chuan Fa". In 1971 Jon A. Loren started incorporating the concepts of Tai-Chi and Southern Sil-lum into his Kajukenbo classes. This was called Northern Kajukenbo until 1976. In 1976, while staying with  Adriano Emperado in Hawaii, he demonstrated his concepts and techniques and asked if he could call it Tum Pai and bring the name back to life. Adriano Emperado granted permission with the acknowledgment that the original Tum Pai followed a different path than the revised Tum Pai soft style. The name Tum Pai, which means "central way", fits the Tai-Chi concept blended into the Kajukenbo format.\n\n\nIn Hawaii during the early 1960s  Adriano Emperado, along with students Al Dacascos and Al Dela Cruz, incorporated innovations of the style Tum Pai and other martial arts into their Kajukenbo training. Later it became obvious that they were no longer doing Tum Pai and it would have to be named something else. In the mid 60s Al Dacascos moved to Northern California and continued training in the Northern and Southern styles of Sil-lum Kung Fu to enhance his Kajukenbo training. It was in 1965 that the name Chuan Fa was introduced.\n\n\nWun Hop Kuen Do was founded by Al Dacascos, in Cantonese Chinese Wun Hop Kuen Do means "combination fist art style" Wun Hop Kuen Do techniques identify with, and are based on, the Kajukenbo system. This martial arts style incorporates techniques from many different styles including Northern and Southern Kung Fu systems and Escrima. Since this style is always being developed it is not a fixed system. This means that practitioners of the style are always striving to improve it by the incorporation and improvement of useful methods or techniques. In addition the philosophy of remaining "unfixed" also applies to the defense techniques, in that there is no defined response to a given situation, and they attempt to fit the situation as it arises. This idea leads to self-defense that is creative and allows one to think about what is the best response. This is one of the primary things that sets this style apart from most others, it is a martial art that asks you to think for yourself and use your own common sense to actually see what you should do next.  There are many drills to allow practice of this type of fluidity and creativity that lead to the ability to respond reflexively to any situation \u2014 which is in contrast to many other training methods where one is supposed to mimic techniques which are often not practical, except under very defined circumstances.\n\n\nIn 1967 Charles Gaylord, along with other accomplished Kajukenbo practitioners Aleju Reyes, Joe Halbuna, Tony Ramos, and Al Dacascos formed the Kajukenbo Association of America (KAA.) The KAA organization lasted until the early 1970s, but it was brought back in 1980 under the leadership of Charles Gaylord who had recently received his 9th degree black belt under founder Adrian Emperado. Fifteen years later in September 1995, the KAA\u2019s black belts promoted Charles Gaylord to the honorary rank of 10th degree black belt. Grandmaster Gaylords traditional Kajukenbo curriculum continues to be taught by his chief instructors who operate Kajukenbo schools in Hawaii and other parts of the United States.<ref name="Usadojo"/>\n\n\nDeveloped by Prof. Vincent Holck, the son of Joseph Holck and nephew of Peter YY Choo, Ma Prof. Holck, Matsuno professes his teachings of Kajukenbo under two systems.\n\nThe first system of Kajukenbo is the Matsuno Ryu Goshinjutsu. This system dedicates the introduction of Danzan Ryu Jujutsu, by his father, into the Kajukenbo system.\n\nThe second system of Kajukenbo is the Matsuno Kajukenbo Kai which dedicates the introduction of kickboxing into the Kajukenbo system by his Uncle, Prof. Peter Choo.\n\n\n\nThe 1982 childrens book A Bundle of Sticks by Pat Rhoads Mauser, is the story of a fifth-grade boy Ben Tyler, who is being bullied by a much larger boy named Boyd Bradshaw. One day Ben comes home from school with a badly bruised nose, so Bens parents decide to enroll him in a Kajukenbo martial arts school. Ben reluctantly agrees to attend the school because his mother has already paid the instructor who is known only as Sifu. At first Ben thinks he will not enjoy Kajukenbo, but he eventually discovers how valuable his training is when he successfully defends himself from Boyd.\n\n\n\n\n\n* http://www.koamartialarts.com u'introduction', u'of', u'kickboxing', u'into', u'the', u'kajukenbo', u'system', u'by', u'his', u'uncle', u'prof', u'peter', u'choo', u'the', u'1982', u'childrens', u'book', u'a', u'bundle', u'of', u'sticks', u'by', u'pat', u'rhoads', u'mauser', u'is', u'the', u'story', u'of', u'a', u'fifth', u'grade', u'boy', u'ben', u'tyler', u'who', u'is', u'being', u'bullied', u'by', u'a', u'much', u'larger', u'boy', u'named', u'boyd', u'bradshaw', u'one', u'day', u'ben', u'comes', u'home', u'from', u'school', u'with', u'a', u'badly', u'bruised', u'nose', u'so', u'bens', u'parents', u'decide', u'to', u'enroll', u'him', u'in', u'a', u'kajukenbo', u'martial', u'arts', u'school', u'ben', u'reluctantly', u'agrees', u'to', u'attend', u'the', u'school', u'because', u'his', u'mother', u'has', u'already', u'paid', u'the', u'instructor', u'who', u'is', u'known', u'only', u'as', u'sifu', u'at', u'first', u'ben', u'thinks', u'he', u'will', u'not', u'enjoy', u'kajukenbo', u'but', u'he', u'eventually', u'discovers', u'how', u'valuable', u'his', u'training', u'is', u'when', u'he', u'successfully', u'defends', u'himself', u'from', u'boyd', u'http', u'www', u'koamartialarts', u'com', u'kajukenbo', u'ohana', u'association', u'http', u'kajukenbo', u'com', u'the', u'kajukenbo', u'cafe', u'http', u'www', u'kajukenbo', u'org', u'kajukenbo', u'org', u'http', u'kajukenboinfo', u'com', u'kajukenbo', u'the', u'original', u'mixed', u'martial', u'art', u'http', u'www', u'kajukenbo', u'be', u'kajukenbo', u'belgium', u'kajukenbo', u'belgium', u'http', u'www', u'kajukenbo', u'fr', u'kajukenbo', u'france', u'http', u'www', u'kajukenbocanada', u'com', u'kajukenbo', u'canada', u'http', u'www', u'kajukenbo', u'info', u'kajukenbo', u'technique', u'html', u'techniques', u'of', u'kajukenbo', u'category', u'kajukenbo', u'category', u'hybrid', u'martial', u'arts', u'category', u'north', u'american', u'martial', u'arts', u'category', u'martial', u'arts', u'in', u'the', u'united', u'states'])
Row(id=326141, title=u'Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\n|feast_day= 3 May\n|venerated_in= Eastern Orthodox church\n|image= Nikolaj-Velimirovi\u0107.jpg\n|imagesize= 220px\n|caption=\n|birth_place= Leli\u0107, Valjevo, Principality of Serbia\n|death_place= South Canaan Township, Wayne County, Pennsylvania, U.S.\n|titles= Holy bishop\n|beatified_date=\n|beatified_place=\n|beatified_by=\n|canonized_date= 24 May 2003\n|canonized_place=\n|canonized_by= Serbian Orthodox Church\n|attributes= Vested as a bishop\n|patronage=\n|major_shrine= Leli\u0107 monastery, Serbia\n\n\nSaint Nikolai Velimirovich of Ohrid and \u017di\u010da or Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 (Serbian Cyrillic: \u041d\u0438\u043a\u043e\u043b\u0430\u0458 \u0412\u0435\u043b\u0438\u043c\u0438\u0440\u043e\u0432\u0438\u045b; &nbsp;\u2013 ) was bishop of the eparchies of Ohrid and Eparchy of \u017di\u010da|\u017di\u010da (1920-1956) in the Serbian Orthodox Church, an influential theological writer and a highly gifted orator, known as The New Chrysostom.<ref name="orthodoxinfo">\n\nHis birth name was Nikola. As a young man, he came close to dying of dysentery, and decided that he would dedicate his life to God if he survived. Survive he did, and was tonsured as a monk under the name Nikolaj. He was ordained into the clergy, and quickly became an important leader and spokesperson for the Serbian Orthodox Church, especially in its relations with the West. When the Nazi Germany occupied Yugoslavia in World War II, Velimirovi\u0107 was imprisoned and eventually taken to Dachau concentration camp in Germany.\n\nAfter being liberated by the Allies of World War II at the end of the war, he chose not to return to Yugoslavia (which had a Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia by that time). He moved to the United States in 1946, where he remained until his death in 1956. He strongly supported the unity of all Eastern Orthodox Church and established particularly good relationships with the Anglican and Episcopal Church (United States).\n\n\n\n\nNikola Velimirovi\u0107 was born in the small village of Leli\u0107, Valjevo, Serbia, on the day of the feast of Saint Naum of Ohrid, whose monastery would later be his episcopal see. He was the first of nine children born to the family of pious farmers. Being very weak, he was baptised soon after his birth in the \u0106elije monastery, where his relics are now resting. He was given the name Nikola because Saint Nicholas was the familys patron saint.\n\nThe first lessons about God, Jesus Christ, the lives of the saints and the holy days of the Church year were provided to him by his mother, who also regularly took him to the \u0106elije monastery for prayer and Holy Communion.\n\n\n\nFile:St. Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 as a student.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Velimirovi\u0107 as a student\nHis formal education also began in the \u0106elije monastery and continued in Valjevo. He applied for admission into the Military Academy, but was refused because he didnt pass the physical exam. He was admitted to the Seminary of Saint Sava in Belgrade, where he \u2014 apart from the standard subjects \u2014 explored a significant number of writings of both Eastern and Western theological authors. He graduated in 1902.\n\nAs an outstanding student, he was chosen to continue his studies in Russia and Western Europe. He had a gift for languages and soon possessed a good knowledge of Russian, French and German. From St. Petersburg he went to Switzerland and obtained his doctorate of divinity from the Old Catholic Theological Faculty at the University of Berne. He received his doctorate in Theology in 1908, with the dissertation entitled Faith in the Resurrection of Christ as the Foundation of the Dogmas of the Apostolic Church. This original work was written in German and published in Switzerland in 1910, and later translated into Serbian. The dissertation for his Doctorate in philosophy was prepared at Oxford and defended in Geneva, in French. The title was Berkeleys Philosophy.\n\n\n\nIn the autumn of 1909, Nikola returned home and became seriously ill with dysentery. He decided to become a monk and devote his life to God if he stayed alive. At the end of 1909 his health got better and he was tonsured a monk, receiving the name Nikolaj. He was soon ordained a hieromonk and then elevated to the rank of Archimandrite.\n\n\n\nArchimandrite Nikolaj was chosen to be a professor in the Seminary of St. Sava in Belgrade. It was decided that he needed to accomplish Orthodox studies before becoming a teacher. As was the custom in those days, he was sent to Imperial Russia to continue his studies. After his return to Belgrade in 1911, when he was thirty-one years old, he was appointed to the University of Belgrades Academy of Theology, teaching philosophy, logic, history and foreign languages. His talks and sermons were read avidly throughout Serbia. This was partly because his exposition of the Christian faith was inspired by the life of St. Sava, the national patron saint of Serbia. In the Church itself he had only the authority of his words and personality: he was just a monk, but even so he seemed destined to exert great influence. It was not surprising that in 1915 he was entrusted with a mission to Great Britain in order to gain the co-operation of the Church of England in educating the young students who had been evacuated when the Austrian, German and Bulgarian forces threatened to overwhelm the country. One of his students in Belgrade was Justin Popovi\u0107.\n\n\n\nIn his lifetime, Father Nikolaj visited the United States four times. He visited England in 1910. He studied English and was capable of addressing an audience and making a strong impression on the listeners. Shortly after the outbreak of World War I this contributed to his appointment by the Serbian government to a mission in the United States. In 1915, as an unknown Serbian monk, he toured most of the major U.S. cities, where he held numerous lectures, fighting for the union of the Serbs and South Slavic peoples. This mission gained grounds: America sent over 20,000 volunteers to Europe, most of whom later fought on the Salonika Front. During Velimirovi\u0107s US-campaign occurred the great retreat of the Serbian Army through the mountains of Albania. He embarked home in 1916; as his country was now in enemy hands, he went to England instead. His eloquence and character made him an unofficial spokesman of his people. His success was such that not only did he fulfill his mission, but he was also awarded a Doctor of Divinity honoris causa from the University of Cambridge.\n\nHe gave a series of notable lectures at St. Margarets, Westminster, and preached in St. Pauls Cathedral as well as in other cathedrals and churches throughout the land. He also preached in the Episcopal chapel, where his practical discourse attracted many hearers. Velimirovi\u0107 became celebrated. At the same time he was active in the promotion of the Serbian Relief Fund and was successful in obtaining a university education for Serb students, several of whom, including Bishop Irinej of Dalmatia, took their degrees before they returned to their own country after the war. In 1918, Velimirovi\u0107 returned to the United States for a second visit, but as a celebrity who was to address the American people as a whole on behalf of Serbian relief. In 1919 he received another Honorary Doctorate of Divinity from the University of Glasgow. From Glasgow his repute as a theological scholar and preacher spread throughout the United Kingdom. After the war, he returned to Belgrade in April 1919.\n\n\n\nIn 1919, Archimandrite Nikolaj was consecrated Bishop of \u017di\u010da but did not remain long in that diocese, being asked to take over the office of Bishop in the Eparchy of Ohrid (1920-1931) and Eparchy of Ohrid and Bitola (1931-1936) in southern parts of Kingdom of Yugoslavia. Whether that was his own wish is not clear. It was in a way a mission post for the people of the lately recovered Serbian territory were backward and there were still vestiges of the Ottoman days still prevailing in habit, pagan superstition and even black magic.\n\nThe percentage of illiteracy was very high and the population was for the most part very poor. He had many difficulties there but a great number of humble folk became attached to him and felt that even to touch his hand was to receive a blessing. For many years his seat was the ancient monastery of Sveti Naum at the south end of the Lake Ohrid. It was there that he wrote Ohridski Prologue. In 1920, for the third time, he journeyed again to the United States, this time on a mission to organize the Serbian Orthodox Diocese of North America.\nThe Outlook Magazine carried an interesting story about Bishop Nikolaj after visiting the United States in their 23 February 1921 issue (pp.&nbsp;285\u201386):<blockquote>"He is Bishop of Ohrid, near the Albanian border, and is a popular and beloved leader of the Serbian Orthodox Church.  Last summer an American accompanied him on a journey into the mountains, where he was to preach in a remote village church. They found the roads lined for twenty-five miles with men, women and children, who had journeyed far on foot to greet him, and in the mountain church the densely packed people had been standing all through the night...."</blockquote>\n\nFinally, in 1927, he came to the U.S. once more, to speak before the Institute of Politics in Williamstown, Massachusetts. A reporter covering the event, wrote:<blockquote>"His black monks robe, his long black beard, and his dark, living eyes, set in an oval Slavic face, gave him an appearance which contrasted as strongly with that of conventionally dressed professors and diplomats as did his views of the common problems of world peace contrast with theirs. His charm and urbanity of manner, the completeness of his grasp upon international problems only emphasized the difference in his thought....Bishop Nikolaj, speaking from the point of view of a civilization in which men still are more important than institutions, points out that peace or war is a matter of the way men think and feel toward each other, and that all other things are only outgrowths of this. The greatest force for affecting mens attitudes toward each other he believes would be a reunited Christian Church" (Living Age, Vol. 335-36, 1928-29).</blockquote>\n\nIn 1935, he reconstructed the cemetery of the fallen German soldiers from World War I in Bitola. During the Milan Stojadinovi\u0107 administration when the Patriarchate became vacant (after the poisoning of Patriarch Varnava and the failed attempt at ratifying a Concordat with the Holy See) he was reportedly an obvious choice but allegedly too greatly identified with the democratic idealism of England and the United States of America (places he frequently visited) while Stojadinovi\u0107 leaned towards Germany and Italy.\n\nStill, except for his unwavering opposition to Communism, there was very little that could be labelled "political" in Velimirovi\u0107s ministrations and writings. The most that could be said was that he strove to keep Serbia alive after it had been merged into the larger state of Yugoslavia. He started a movement for the renewal and care of the old churches, shrines and cemeteries in Macedonia. It had been at his suggestion that the large illustrated volume South Slav Monuments was compiled and then published in London, and when he was made Bishop of Ohrid he began that work of restoration which still continues to this day.\n\n\n\nIn 1936, he finally resumed his original office of Bishop in the Eparchy of \u017di\u010da, returning to the Monastery of \u017di\u010da not far distant from Valjevo and Leli\u0107, where he was born. At \u017di\u010da he started a movement for the revival of the Serb Church, evoking the inspiration of its patron saint Saint Sava. He seldom gave a sermon without mentioning the saints name. Eventually in exile he wrote the only substantial biography of St. Sava which we have. In the years preceding the outbreak of World War II, Velimirovi\u0107, continuing his campaign for a Serb revival, instituted what may be called a Society of Prayer and renewed the ancient custom of Christians gathering together to visit a friends house for prayer, in that way making Christianity social rather than individualistic and solitary. This social prayer extended over a large area and drew national attention. It was described in the newspapers, and pictures of the benign and now almost apostolic countenance of Bishop Nikolaj appeared in Sunday editions.\n\n\n\nDuring World War II, in 1941, as soon as the German forces occupied Yugoslavia, Bishop Nikolaj was arrested by the Nazis in the Monastery of \u017di\u010da, after which he was confined in the Monastery of Ljubostinja. Later he was transferred to the Monastery of Vojlovica Monastery (near Pan\u010devo) in which he was confined together with the Serbian Patriarch Gavrilo V until the end of 1944. On 15 September 1944, both Serbian Patriarch Gavrilo V (Do\u017ei\u0107) and Bishop Nikolaj were sent to Dachau concentration camp, which was at that time the main Dachau concentration camp#priests arrested by the Nazis. Both Velimirovi\u0107 and Do\u017ei\u0107 were held as special prisoners (Ehrenh\xe4ftlinge) imprisoned in the so-called Ehrenbunker (or Prominentenbunker) separated from the work camp area, together with high-ranking Nazi enemy officers and other prominent prisoners whose arrests had been dictated by Hitler directly.<ref>Leisner, Karl. Priesterweihe und Primiz im KZ Dachau, pg. 183, LIT Verlag Berlin-Hamburg-M\xfcnster, 2004; ISBN 3825872777, 9783825872779\n\nIn August 1943 German general Hermann Neubacher became special emissary of the German Foreign Office for Southeastern Europe. From 11 September 1943, he was also made responsible for Albania. In December 1944, Velimirovi\u0107 and Do\u017ei\u0107 were transferred from Dachau to Slovenia, together with Milan Nedi\u0107, the Serbian collaborationist PM, as the Nazis attempted to make use of Patriarch Gavrilos and Nikolajs authority among the Serbs in order to gain allies in the anti-Communist movements. Contrary to claims of torture and abuse at the camp, Patriarch Do\u017ei\u0107 testified himself that both he and Velimirovi\u0107 were treated normally.<ref>Glasnik Pravoslavne Crkve, July 1946, pp 66-67. Also in Do\u017ei\u0107 G., Memoari patrijarha srpskog Gavrila (Beograd: Sfairos 1990), entries for December 1944.\n\nLater, Velimirovi\u0107 and Patriarch Gavrilo (Do\u017ei\u0107) were moved to Austria, and were finally liberated by the US 36th Infantry Division (United States) in Tyrol (state) in 1945. He was physically weakened by these vicissitudes. He was brought to England. Velimirovi\u0107 and Do\u017ei\u0107 were at Westminster Abbey at the baptism of King Peter II of Yugoslavias son and heir, Crown Prince Alexander of Yugoslavia. Velimirovi\u0107 preached a very moving sermon at the Serb chapel in the house in Egerton Gardens. But there was no place for him in England such as there had been during the First World War. Patriarch Gavrilo, being old and ill, returned to what then came to be known as the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, where he died soon after his arrival. Velimirovi\u0107 opted to emigrate to the United States.\n\nHe was allowed to spend the last years of his life in the United States, only returning once to England when he came to consecrate the Church of St Sava in 1952, an occasion when Serbs in the thousands rallied from the mines and factories of England to the walls of the great church in Ladbroke Grove. The sacred edifice was packed and the overflow crowd streamed all the way to the London Underground, with Velimirovi\u0107s voice sounding through the air on loudspeakers.\n\n\nAfter the war he never returned to the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, but after spending some time in Europe, he finally immigrated as a refugee to the United States in 1946. There, in spite of his health problems, he continued his missionary work, for which he is considered An Apostle and Missionary of the New Continent (quote by Fr. Alexander Schmemann), and has also been enlisted as an American Saint\n\nHe taught at several Eastern Orthodox Church seminary such as St. Savas Seminary (Libertyville, Illinois), Saint Tikhons Orthodox Theological Seminary and Monastery (South Canaan, Pennsylvania), and St. Vladimirs Orthodox Theological Seminary (now in Crestwood, New York).\n\n\n\nVelimirovi\u0107 died on 18 March 1956, while in prayer at the foot of his bed before the Liturgy, at the Russian Orthodox Monastery of St. Tikhon in South Canaan Township, Wayne County, Pennsylvania in the United States. He was buried near the tomb of poet Jovan Du\u010di\u0107 at the Monastery of St. Sava at Libertyville, Illinois. After the fall of communism, his remains were ultimately re-buried in his home town of Leli\u0107 on 12 May 1991, next to his parents and his nephew, Bishop Jovan Velimirovi\u0107. On 19 May 2003, the Holy Assembly of Bishops of the Serbian Orthodox Church recognized Bishop Nikolaj (Velimirovi\u0107) of Ohrid and \u017di\u010da as a saint and decided to include him into the calendar of saints of Holy Orthodox Church (18 March and 3 May).\n\n\n\nSeveral of Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107\u2019s writings and public speeches have been identified by historians as containing Antisemitism rhetoric and/or hate speech directed at Jews.\n\nNotably, the first written record of Velimirovi\u0107s antisemitic beliefs comes over a decade before the start of World War II and his stay at the Dachau concentration camp. In fact, the first chronicled case of Velimirovi\u0107 expressing antisemitic beliefs dates back to a 1927 sermon delivered in the United States.<ref name=":0">\n\nFrom the 1927 sermon titled \u201cA Story about the Wolf and the Lamb,\u201d Velimirovi\u0107\u2019s proclamations are summarized by social psychologist Jovan Byford: <blockquote>\u201cIn his take on the well known Christian parable about the wolf and the lamb, Velimirovi\u0107 referred to \u201cJewish leaders in Jerusalem\u201d at the time of the crucifixion as \u201cwolves,\u201d whose thirst for blood of the Lamb of God was motivated by their \u201cgod-hating nationalism.\u201d<ref name=":0" /></blockquote>Byfords summary of Velimirovi\u0107s "A Story about the Wolf and the Lamb" is significant for it serves as evidence that Velimirovi\u0107 may have utilized biblical undertones and Christian parable as a means of validating his antisemitic statements to his followers. An interview that Jovan Byford conducted with Mladen Obradovi\u0107 (leader of Serbian far-right political organization Obraz (organization)) may suggest that this explanation still persists among some members of Serbian Orthodox Church society. A contemporary defender of Velimirovi\u0107s reputation and saint status, Obradovi\u0107 defends the antisemitic writings of Velimimirovi\u0107 by stating that Velimirovi\u0107s words only echo what had been written in early Christian texts:<ref name=":1">  <blockquote>\u201cYou have the very words of the Lord Jesus Christ when he says to the Pharisees that they are a \u201cbrood of vipers\u201d or that their father is the Devil; Bishop Nikolaj merely quotes the Gospels."<ref name=":1" /></blockquote>In a speech delivered in 1936 at the \u017dica Monastery in Serbia, Velimirovi\u0107 spoke out against what he perceived to be a Jewish threat to Christianity in front of a distinguished audience that included Yugoslavian Prime Minister Milan Stojadinovi\u0107. Velimirovi\u0107 used specific lines of this speech to accuse Jews of leading a secretive, coordinated effort against Christianity and "faith in real God".<ref name=":2">\n\nVelimirovi\u0107s writing in Words to the Serbian People Through the Prison Window is generally seen as the strongest evidence of the Canonization Bishop holding antisemitic beliefs. Notably, many proponents of Velimirovi\u0107s ideology suggest that the work is not definitive evidence of the Bishops true ideology and beliefs about Jews and Judaism because they claim that it was written under duress during his time at Dachau concentration camp. The excerpts from Velimirovi\u0107s Words to the Serbian People Through the Prison Window that attract the most attention from scholars studying antisemitism are quoted in Jovan Byfords Denial and Repression of Antisemitism: Post-Communist Remembrance of the Serbian Bishop Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 as follows:<blockquote>"The Devil teaches them Jews; the Devil taught them how to stand against the son of God, Jesus Christ. The Devil taught them through the centuries how to fight against the sons of Christ, against the children of light, against the followers of the Gospel and eternal life Christians. ...<ref name=":2" /></blockquote><blockquote>"Europe knows nothing other than what Jews serve up as knowledge. It believes nothing other than what Jews order it to believe. It knows the value of nothing until Jews impose their own measure of values \u2026 all modern ideas including democracy, and strikes, and socialism, and atheism, and religious tolerance, and pacifism, and global revolution, and capitalism, and communism are the inventions of Jews, or rather their father, the Devil.<ref name=":3"></blockquote>Additionally, Jovan Byford identifies the antisemitic ideology of Velimirovi\u0107 in the work, Indian Letters in which the figure of a Jewish woman portrays Satan.<ref name=":3" /> Notably, this example of Velimirovi\u0107s antisemitic portrayal is again linked to Conspiracy theory as Velimirovi\u0107 describes the woman as standing for, "all destructive and secret associations plotting against Christianity, religion, and the state."<ref name=":3" />\n\nDespite accusations of antisemitism, it is recorded that Velimirovi\u0107 protected a Jewish family by facilitating their escape from Nazi-occupied Serbia. Ela Trifunovi\u0107 (Ela Nayhaus), wrote to the Serbian Orthodox Church in 2001, claiming that she had spent 18 months hiding in the Ljubostinja monastery to which she was smuggled by Velimirovi\u0107, guarded and later helped move on with false papers.<ref>\u0421\u0432\u0435\u0442\u0438 \u0412\u043b\u0430\u0434\u0438\u043a\u0430 \u041d\u0438\u043a\u043e\u043b\u0430\u0458 \u041e\u0445\u0440\u0438\u0434\u0441\u043a\u0438 \u0438 \u0416\u0438\u0447\u043a\u0438, (Holy Bishop Nikolaj of Ohrid and \u017di\u010da)(\u017di\u010da Monastery, Kraljevo 2003), p. 179 Historians inclined to side with views that Velimirovi\u0107s writings prove that he held antisemitic beliefs note that this one incidence of the Bishop saving a Jewish family is commonly exaggerated by pro-Velimirovi\u0107 groups as evidence of his universal kindness and selflessness against the several confirmed antisemitic writings tied to Velimirovi\u0107.\n\n===Velimirovi\u0107 and Hitler===\nAdolf Hitler decorated Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 in 1935 for his contributions to the restoration of a German military cemetery in Bitola in 1926.<ref>Byford, J., "Denial and Repression of Antisemitism: Post-communist Remembrance of the Serbian Bishop Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107" (CEU Press, 2008), p. 47.<!--ISSN/ISBN needed--> Some claim that the order was returned in protest at German aggression in 1941.<ref>See letter "Poveli ste se za mi\u0161ljenjem Filipa Koena" in Danas, 27 July 2002.\n\nIn a treatise on St. Sava in 1935, he supported Hitlers treatment of the German national church<ref>Radi\u0107, R. Dr\u017eava i verske zajednice 1945-1970 (Institut za noviju istoriju Srbije; Beegrad 1970), p. 80 and is quoted as saying:<blockquote>"However, a due respect is to be to the current German Leader, who being a simple craftsman and a man from the people, realized that nationalism without faith is an anomaly, a cold and insecure mechanism. And so, in the XX century, he came to the idea of Saint Sava, and as a layman undertook among his people that most important work, befitting a saint, a genius and a hero. And for us that work has been accomplished by Saint Sava, the first among the saints, the first among the geniuses and the first among the heroes in our history. He accomplished it perfectly, he accomplished it without fight and without blood, and he accomplished it not yesterday or the day before, but 700 years ago."<ref>See "Nationalism of Saint Sava", in Collected Works of Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 (Vladimir Maksimovi\u0107: Belgrade 1996), page 36.<!--ISSN/ISBN needed--></blockquote>\n\n===Velimirovi\u0107 and Ljoti\u0107===\nVelimirovi\u0107 had a high opinion of Dimitrije Ljoti\u0107, a Serbian fascist politician and German collaborationist.<ref>Subotic, D., Episkop Nikolaj i Pravoslavni Bogomoljacki Pokret (Nova Iskra, beograd 1996), p. 195 et al. Also Byford, J, "Potiskivanje i poricanje antisemtizma", Helsin\u0161ki odbor za ljudska prava, Beograd, Ogledi, Br. 6, p. 33 and Marti\u0107, M., 1980, "Dimitrije Ljoti\u0107 and the Yugoslav National Movement Zbor, 1935-1945" in "East European Quarterly," Vol. 16, No. 2, pp. 219-39.\n\nIn an interview given in the United States in 1953, Velimirovi\u0107 claimed that he was the spiritual gray eminence behind the nationalist and collaborating extreme-right ZBOR organization.<ref>Popov, N. (1993) Srpski populizam od marginalne do dominantne pojave. (Serbian populism from a marginal to a dominant phenomenon). Vreme 133:1\u201335. More on Velimirovi\u0107 and Ljoti\u0107 also in Cohen, P., Riesman, D, Serbias Secret War: Propaganda and the Deceit of History (Texas A&M University Press 1997), Chapter I, page 21 (also note 95), page 26, page 59 The military arm of that organization (SDK - Srpski Dobrovolja\u010dki Korpus - Serbian Volunteer Corps (World War II)) was fighting against both Yugoslav Partisans and Chetniks in World War II and was responsible for numerous civilian executions in Serbia of both Serbs and other nationals (Jews, Roma, etc.) When the leader of ZBOR, Dimitrije Ljoti\u0107, was arrested in 1940 by the Kingdom of Yugoslavia government, Velimirovi\u0107 protested in a letter to the PM, Dragi\u0161a Cvetkovi\u0107.<ref>Jankovi\u0107, M., Vladika Nikolaj: \u017eivot, misao i delo, (Bishop Nikolaj: his life, thought and work). 3 vols. (Valjevo: Eparhija \u0160aba\u010dko\u2013Valjevska 2002) Velimirovi\u0107 attended Ljoti\u0107s funeral in 1945 and spoke very positively of him even though it was already known that Ljoti\u0107 was collaborating with the Germans. He spoke of Ljoti\u0107 as an "ideologue of Serbian nationalism".<ref>Kosti\u0107, B. (1991). Za Istoriju Na\u0161ih Dana: Odlomci iz zapisa za vreme okupacije (For the history of our days: extracts from a diary at the time of the occupation). Beograd: Nova Iskra and Suboti\u0107, D. (1993). Pravoslavlje izme\u0111u Istoka i Zapada u bogoslovnoj misli Nikolaja Velimirovi\u0107a i Justina Popovi\u0107a Orthodoxy between East and West in the religious thought of Nikolaj Velimirovi\u0107 and Justin Popovi\u0107. In \u010covek i Crkva u Vrtlogu Krize: \u0160ta nam nudi pravoslavlje danas? Man and Church in the vortex of crisis: What can Orthodoxy offer us today?, ed. G. \u017divkovi\u0107. Valjevo: Glas Crkve.<!--page(s), ISSN/ISBN needed-->\n\n===Velimirovi\u0107 and Germans===\nIn spite of accusations of collaboration leveled during Communist times, some of Velimirovi\u0107s actions and writings were directed against the Germans who got suspicious of him when he supported the coup in April 1941.<ref>Jevti\u0107, A., "Kosovska misao i opredeljenje Episkopa Nikolaja", Glas crkve, 1988, No. 3, p. 24<!--ISSN/ISBN needed--> They suspected him of collaborating with the Chetniks and formally arrested him and kept him first in Ljubostinja Monastery in 1941 and then in 1944 in Dachau concentration camp.\n\nIn Dachau, he was imprisoned in Ehrenbunker, together with other clergy and high-ranking Nazi enemy officers, and was allowed to wear his own religious clothes, having access to the officers canteen. It is claimed that he was never tortured and had access to officers medical services. Contrary to the reports that Velimirovi\u0107 was liberated when the Americans 36th Division reached Dachau, both he and Patriarch Do\u017ei\u0107 were actually released in December 1944, having spent three months in the camp. They travelled to Slovenia, from where Velimirovic continued first to Austria then to United States.<ref>"Sve\u0161tenici u koncentracionom logoru Dahau", Glasnik Srpske pravoslavne crkve - Serbian Orthodox Church Official Gazette, volume XXXVII, July 1946, p. 66-67. See also Serbias Secret War: Propaganda and the Deceit of History (Texas A&M University Press 1997), pp. 58-60, 105-107.<ISSN/ISBN needed--> However, there is documented evidence, including photographs of Bishop Nikolaj (Velimirovi\u0107) and Patriarch Gavrilo (Do\u017ei\u0107) present at the baptismal of Prince Alexander (Kara\u0111or\u0111evi\u0107) in London, England, in 1945 before Nikolaj emigrated in 1946 to the U.S. and Patriarch Gavrilo returned home.\n\n\nAmfilohije Radovi\u0107  points out that part of his success lies in his high education and ability to write well and his understanding of European culture.<ref>Radvovic, A. "Bogocovjecanski etos Valdike Nikolaja" in Jevtic, A., Sveti Valdika Nikolaj Ohridski i Zicki (Kraljevo, \u017di\u010da 2003)\n\nVelimirovi\u0107 is viewed as less original by non-theologians. Literary critic Milan Bogdanovi\u0107 claims that everything Velimirovi\u0107 wrote after his Ohrid years did nothing more than paraphrase Orthodox canon and dogma. Bogdanovi\u0107 views him as a conservative who glorified the Church and its ceremonies as an institution. This, however, is explained by true Orthodox thought, because, as Saint John of Damascus writes, "It is for that reason that I say (teach) nothing of what is mine. I briefly express the thoughts and words passed down by Godly and wise men."\n\n\n*http://www.rastko.org.rs/svecovek/duhovnost/vlnikolaj/vlnikolaj-boka.html \u041c\u043e\u0458\u0435 \u0443\u0441\u043f\u043e\u043c\u0435\u043d\u0435 \u0438\u0437 \u0411\u043e\u043a\u0435 (1904) (My memories from Boka)\n*http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/15891 Franz\xf6sisch-slavische K\xe4mpfe in der Bocca di Cattaro (1910)\n*Beyond Sin and Death (1914)\n*http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/13301 The New Ideal in Education (1916)\n*http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/13388 The Religious Spirit of the Slavs (1916)\n*The Spiritual Rebirth of Europe (1917)\n*Orations on the Universal Man (1920)\n*http://www.rastko.org.rs/svecovek/duhovnost/vlnikolaj/vlnikolaj_molitva.html \u041c\u043e\u043b\u0438\u0442\u0432\u0435 \u043d\u0430 \u0458\u0435\u0437\u0435\u0440\u0443 (1922)\n*Thoughts on Good and Evil (1923)\n*Homilias, volumes I and II (1925)\n*http://www.rastko.org.rs/istorija/sv_jovan_vladimir_c.html \u0427\u0438\u0442\u0430\u043d\u043a\u0430 \u043e \u0421\u0432\u0435\u0442\u043e\u043c\u0435 \u043a\u0440\u0430\u0459\u0443 \u0408\u043e\u0432\u0430\u043d\u0443 \u0412\u043b\u0430\u0434\u0438\u043c\u0438\u0440\u0443 ()\n*http://www.westsrbdio.org/prolog/my.html? u'to', u'overwhelm', u'the', u'country', u'one', u'of', u'his', u'students', u'in', u'belgrade', u'was', u'justin', u'popovi', u'in', u'his', u'lifetime', u'father', u'nikolaj', u'visited', u'the', u'united', u'states', u'four', u'times', u'he', u'visited', u'england', u'in', u'1910', u'he', u'studied', u'english', u'and', u'was', u'capable', u'of', u'addressing', u'an', u'audience', u'and', u'making', u'a', u'strong', u'impression', u'on', u'the', u'listeners', u'shortly', u'after', u'the', u'outbreak', u'of', u'world', u'war', u'i', u'this', u'contributed', u'to', u'his', u'to', u'austria', u'then', u'to', u'united', u'states', u'ref', u'sve', u'tenici', u'u', u'koncentracionom', u'logoru', u'dahau', u'glasnik', u'srpske', u'pravoslavne', u'crkve', u'serbian', u'rs', u'istorija', u'sv_jovan_vladimir_c', u'html', u'http', u'www', u'westsrbdio', u'org', u'prolog', u'my', u'html', u'the', u'prologue', u'from', u'ohrid', u'1926', u'the', u'faith', u'of', u'from', u'india', u'http', u'www', u'rastko', u'org', u'rs', u'svecovek', u'duhovnost', u'vlnikolaj', u'vlnikolaj', u'istokzapad', u'html', u'iznad', u'istoka', u'i', u'zapada', u'above', u'east',
