u'states', u'category', u'organizations', u'based', u'in', u'detroit'])
Row(id=474383, title=u'Tourism in Argentina', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\nFile:Argentina tourist regions.svg|thumb|Tourist regions of Argentina:<ref name="turismo.gov.ar">http://www.turismo.gov.ar/eng/menu.htm Ministry of Tourism of Argentina: Regions Argentine Northwest (orange), Mesopotamia, Argentina (light green), Cuyo (Argentina) (beige), C\xf3rdoba Province, Argentina|C\xf3rdoba (dark green), Buenos Aires (consisting of Buenos Aires City and Buenos Aires Province; light blue) and Argentine Patagonia (dark blue)\n\nArgentina is provided with a vast territory and a huge variety of climates and microclimates ranging from tundra and polar climate in the south to the tropical climate in the north, through a vast expanse of temperate climate and natural wonders like the Aconcagua, the highest  mountain in the world outside the Himalayas, the widest river and estuary of the planet (the R\xedo de la Plata), the huge and very mighty Iguaz\xfa Falls, some of the flattest and wide meadows-plains of planet Earth (as the Humid Pampas, a large ocean-sea coast in the Argentine Sea), Culture of Argentina, customs and Argentine cuisine famous internationally, a higher degree of development (very high compared to other Latin American countries), good quality of life and people, and relatively well prepared infrastructure make this country one of the most visited of America.\n\nMainly for its beautiful landscapes and then for its cultural heritage, Argentina receives massive amounts of travelers. The Argentine territory stretches from the highest peaks of the Andes in the west to colita del norte rivers and extensive beaches and cliffs of Argentine Sea in the east; from the tropical rainforest of the Yungas north to the valleys, glaciers, lakes and Bosque Andino Patag\xf3nico of Andean Patagonia in the south, and to Argentine Antarctica. Through the warm landscapes of tropical climates contrasting, in a huge gradient microclimates, the polar climates or extensive and very fertile Temperate grasslands, savannas, and shrublandss with the World\xb4s most flatter plains contrasting with the highest mountains outside Asia, contrasted with also vast desert areas plethoric of geoforms for the annual running extensive and extreme Dakar Rally, the high mountain ranges, the pleasant Sierras pampeanas and the temperate Atlantic beaches and its extensive coastlines. The huge distances require in most cases air travel. The Misiones rainforest, Argentine Yungas and areas of the Andean Patagonia are scientifically considered as biodiversity hotspots large areas worldwide. The great biodiversity and the large number of different landscapes and Climate of Argentinas make Argentina a diverse country where appear to meet multiple countries together harmoniously (fertile temperates, deserts, cold forest, warm tropicals and subtropical jungles, glacier areas, forests, maritimes with cliffs, rias and fjord s etc.).\n\nThe country presents entire range of possible climates: temperate, dry warm, humid warm, cold dry, cold humid, semi-arid, steppe, subantarctic, subtropical, snowy, cold mountain, and a huge variety of microclimates.\n\nArgentina has been upgrading its worldwide presence as a tourism destination by increasing the investment on international tourism. The latest push can be seen by Aerolineas Argentinas, the countrys national airline, adding international routes from the United States and Europe. There are also rumors that they will join a major airline alliance soon.\n\nArgentina has enjoyed the visit of 5.80 million tourists in the year 2011 according to the World Tourism Organization, the first most visited country in South America and the second most visited of all of Latin America, after Mexico.<ref name="OMT2008">Volume 6 No. 2 Page 30\n\nForeign tourists mainly come from Brazil, Chile, Uruguay, Paraguay, Bolivia, Peru, Ecuador, Colombia, Venezuela, Costa Rica, Mexico, Cuba, Dominican Republic, US, Canada, China, South Korea, Japan, Australia and Europeans from Spain, Italy, France, Germany, United Kingdom, Ireland, Netherlands, Belgium, Switzerland, Portugal and Russia.\n\n\nFile:9 de julio (Buenos Aires).JPG|thumb\n* City of Buenos Aires is in the midst of a tourism boom, according to the World Travel & Tourism Council,<ref name=rgi0708>http://www.wttc.travel/  www.wttc.travel Retrieved on 10 March 2008  it reveals strong growth for Argentina Travel and Tourism in 2007<ref>http://www.wttc.travel/eng/News_and_Events/Press/Press_Releases_2007/WTTC_reveals_strong_growth_for_Argentina_Travel__and_Tourism/ WTTC reveals strong growth for Argentina Retrieved on 10 March 2008 and in coming years,  and the prestigious travel and tourism publication; Travel + Leisure Magazine, a monthly publication leader in the world-wide market of travel magazines,  travelers voted Buenos Aires the second most desirable city to visit after Florence, Italy.<ref>http://www.travelandleisure.com/worldsbest/2007/results.cfm?cat=cities  Travel +Leisure Magazine worldsbest/2007 Retrieved on 10 March 2008 Buenos Aires, regarded as the \u201cParis of South America,\u201d offers elegant architecture, exquisite cuisine,  legendary nightlife, and fashionable shopping.\n\nThe most popular tourist sites are found in the historic city core, comprising Montserrat, Buenos Aires and San Telmo. The city was originally constructed around the Plaza de Mayo, the administrative center of the Spanish Empire. To the east of the square is the Casa Rosada, the official seat of the executive branch of the government of Argentina. To the north, the Buenos Aires Metropolitan Cathedral which has stood in the same location since colonial times, and the Banco de la Naci\xf3n Argentina building, a parcel of land originally owned by Juan de Garay. Other important colonial institutions were Buenos Aires Cabildo, to the west, which was renovated during the construction of Avenida de Mayo and Julio A. Roca. To the south is the Congreso de la Naci\xf3n (National Congress), which currently houses the Academia Nacional de la Historia (National Academy of History). Lastly, to the northwest, is City Hall.\n\nAvenida de Mayo links the Casa Rosada with the Argentine National Congress. On this avenue there are several buildings of cultural, architectural and historical importance, such as Casa de la Cultura (Buenos Aires), the Palacio Barolo and Caf\xe9 Tortoni. Underneath the avenue, the first subte (metro) Line A (Buenos Aires Metro)   in South America, was opened in 1913. The avenue ends at Congressional Plaza, which features a number of monuments and sculptures, including one of Auguste Rodins few surviving original casts of "The Thinker."\n\nThe w:es:Manzana de las Luces ("Illuminated Block") area features the San Ignacio church, the Colegio Nacional de Buenos Aires, and the old city council building (1894 to 1931). This area features tunnels and catacombs, which crossed underneath the Plaza de Mayo during colonial times.\nIn the neighbourhood of San Telmo, Plaza Dorrego hosts an antiques fair on Sundays, complete with tango (dance) shows. They also have tango shows daily at the famous plaza. On weekends they involve many tourists to learn how to dance. Frequent tours and activities are also available at the Church of Nuestra Se\xf1ora de Bethlehem, the San Pedro Telmo Parish and the Antonio Ballv\xe9 Penintetiary Museum. The Museo Hist\xf3rico Nacional de Argentina in Parque Lezama is a few blocks south. The Ayres Porte\xf1os Hostel is a very famous hostel and a tourist attraction, it is decorated and painted by artists from La Boca and possesses a unique collection of local paintings among its walls.\n\nThe borough of Recoleta, Buenos Aires is home to a number of places of interest, including the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes (Buenos Aires), the Biblioteca Nacional de la Rep\xfablica Argentina, the Centro Cultural Recoleta, the Faculty of Law of the Universidad de Buenos Aires, the Bas\xedlica Nuestra Se\xf1ora de Pilar, the Palais de Glace, the Caf\xe9 La Biela and the Cementerio de la Recoleta, where Eva Per\xf3ns crypt can be visited, among those of many other Argentine historical and cultural figures.\n* Iguaz\xfa Falls, located in the northeast, area of subtropical Paran\xe1 forest, on the border with Brazil are one of the worlds natural wonders, has good infrastructure development and touristic with very different walks. Lined with dense forests, the Iguaz\xfa river flows into 275 waterfalls, plunging more than 70 meters with a deafening noise over 2.7&nbsp;km. As this huge volume of water reaches the bottom, spray rises, and rainbows are formed in the sky. A variety of the original fauna and flora completes the setting for the waterfalls within the protection of the Iguaz\xfa National Park. This park, located at eighteen kilometres from Puerto Iguaz\xfa, was declared World Heritage Site by UNESCO. The famous falls are inside this park. The frontier with Brazil goes through the Garganta del Diablo (Devils Throat). The National Park is full of the exotic subtropical vegetation which surrounds the falls and has 2,000 plant species - gigantic trees, ferns, lianas, orchids, - 400 bird species - parrots, hummingbirds, toucans - jaguars and yacar\xe9s (caimans) from the area. Its most impressive fall is called Iguazu Falls. Other important are called Dos Hermanas, Bossetti or \xc1lvar N\xfa\xf1ez in honor of its discoverer, \xc1lvar N\xfa\xf1ez Cabeza de Vaca.\n\nFile:Salta - Convento de San Francisco - Nocturno.jpg|thumb|Basilica and Convent of San Francisco (Salta) in Salta, with the highest church bell of South America\nFile:Vi\xf1edoCafayate.jpg|thumb|left|Vineyard in Cafayate, Province of Salta\n* Salta is a city of colonial architecture with tourist attractions such asch as: Quebrada de San Lorenzo, Calchaqu\xed Valleys, Reservoir Cabra Corral (Embalse General Belgrano), Cafayate, Salinas Grandes (Jujuy and Salta), Iruya (step bound by the Quebrada de Humahuaca and Purmamarca) Cachi, Argentina (through the Cuesta del Obispo) Molinos, Salta, La Caldera, Los Cardones National Park, El Rey National Park or Barit\xfa National Park|Barit\xfa National Pand tae hrk, hot springs of Rosario de la Frontera. The Tren a las Nubes is a train ride through the area of the Puna de Atacama. Puna de Atacama, a land full of mountain ranges, steep mountain paths, valleys,  and gorges. Villages have been built in the small valleys with multi-colored and monochromatic hills covered with huge cacti on the slopes surrounding the village. This region offers landscapes full of contrast, from the high peaks to the salt pans, and the subtropical rain forests, where Latin American culture took root, located in the Northern provinces (Jujuy Province, Salta Province, Catamarca Province, Tucum\xe1n Province|Tucum\xe1n and Santiago del Estero Province<ref>http://www.norteargentino.gov.ar/ Official website of "The North" touristic region). In Northern provinces feature traces of pre-Columbian cultures, mingled with ruins of natives\u2019 villages, as well as forts and constructions dating back to the time of the Conquest and Colonization. The service of this train was interrupted momentarily in July 2005 for repairs, reactivated quickly. Currently, the final destination is the city of San Antonio de los Cobres. The whole Northern provinces combines natural attractions with suitable areas for diverse activities such as mountaineering, trekking, horseback riding, mountain biking, ecotourism, bird-watching, rural tourism, archaeological trips, sailing, canoeing and windsurfing.\n\nFile:Perito Moreno Glacier Patagonia Argentina Luca Galuzzi 2005.JPG|thumb|left|The Perito Moreno Glacier in summer, located in the World Heritage Site Los Glaciares National Park\n* Perito Moreno Glacier, a part of Southern Patagonian Ice Field is a huge glacier that bisects the Argentino Lake and cyclically locks until it produces the breaking of the ice plug. It is located in the Los Glaciares National Park near the Argentine Patagonian city of El Calafate. In any season of the year continuous landslides of huge blocks of ice are produced from massive glaciers forming beautiful icebergs in Argentine lakes. The Perito Moreno Glacier and its neighbors is framed by a landscape of rugged mountains like the Fitz Roy|Chalt\xe9n and large lakes.\n\n* Bariloche: This city is the capital of the southern lakes and important part of the tourist circuit of the Seven Lakes with Villa La Angostura and mountains (Tronador, Cerro Catedral, Cerro L\xf3pez). It is famous for skiing but also great for family trips for older children and sight-seeing, water sports, winter sports, fishing, windsurfing, trekking or hiking, climbing, camping in the Andean forest, sky diving, boat tours and private boats, horseback riding and scuba diving and more. Cerro Catedral is one of the most important ski  centers in South America.  Today, thanks to the investments of entrepreneurs and of municipality has a large tourist flow throughout the year. Also it make similar activities in San Mart\xedn de los Andes, Jun\xedn de los Andes, El Bols\xf3n, R\xedo Negro|El Bols\xf3n, Esquel, Trevelin, Los Antiguos activities are also developed Copahue, Argentina, Caviahue, Argentina.\n\nFile:Ushuaia 2009.jpg|thumb|left|The city of Ushuaia in summer, in the Tierra del Fuego Province, Argentina\n\n* Ushuaia, The southernmost city in the world, in Province of Tierra del Fuego, Antarctica and South Atlantic Islands, typical destination of the south of the country, attracts visitors with a very important tourist with excursions and gastronomy. North of the island, the city of R\xedo Grande, Tierra del Fuego is attracted by the old neighborhood of wooden houses painted varied or subtly and by excellent trout fishing. Further south, it is famous railway from Ushuaia and reaches the Tierra del Fuego National Park, bayside of Lapataia. Cruises are also offered by the Beagle Channel, observing colonies of Otaria flavescenss, and a visit to Faro Les Eclareurso, the beautiful Cami Lake (or Kami) or almost inaccessible Isla de los Estados where is the Lighthouse of the End of the World, the landscape of Fueguan forests takes an almost magical appearance during the austral autumn to be covered with reddish the foliage of the dense forests.\nFile:A - Valle de la Luna, el hongo, San Juan, Argentina.jpg|left|thumb\n* Sierras de C\xf3rdoba,  A mountain range of mild climate and landscapes ranging from the bucolic and wild, there are the main tourist centers: Villa General Belgrano and La Cumbrecita, touristic towns with large central European influence in the Sierras de C\xf3rdoba. Other major cities are Villa Carlos Paz, Cosqu\xedn, C\xf3rdoba|Cosqu\xedn, La Falda, Capilla del Monte, Mina Clavero, Jes\xfas Mar\xeda, C\xf3rdoba|Jes\xfas Mar\xeda or the Great Salt Lake of Mar Chiquita Lake (C\xf3rdoba). The Unidad Tur\xedstica Embalse is the destination of social tourism. the C\xf3rdoba Province It has little towns, historical antiques and cave paintings are found in a pleasant valley landscape, high plains and gorges. The City of C\xf3rdoba, Argentina|C\xf3rdoba also has a great tourist attraction, especially in its valuable building of colonial period or in its urban landscapes. It also has a very good tourist infrastructure with major 5 star hotels, shopping centers of excellence, as well as highlights in the field of gastronomy and fun. The city of C\xf3rdoba is one of the most picturesque of Argentina because it has a historical center with beautiful Baroque architecture Colonial architecture mixed with tall modern buildings that give the city a great tourist attraction. With many contrasting features\u2014 it is both a cultural and tourist-like destination, a traditional and modern city, with an industrialized as well as a home-made production. Large portions of landscape and favorable weather conditions are distinctive in C\xf3rdoba, natural sceneries are mixed with colonial monuments. They are part of the \u201cSierras pampeanas\u201d mountain range, reaching 2,790 m high in the Mount Champaqu\xed. These hills are fertile valleys, deserts and salt mines. All along the way northward, many 17th and 18th century chapels and farmhouses inherited from the Jesuits can be found.\n\nThe Jesuit Block and Estancias of C\xf3rdoba (large cattle ranches) in C\xf3rdoba are a singular sample of the productive organization of the religious members of Compa\xf1\xeda de Jes\xfas in the country, and this can still be seen in a preserved architecture. Though history demonstrated that the farms were acquired for economic purposes in order to support schools and universities, the estancias were of course used \u201cfor missionary purposes, thus turning into religious centers.\u201d Estancias in Jes\xfas Mar\xeda, Caroya, Santa Catalina, La Candelaria and Alta Gracia can be visited along a 250&nbsp;km circuit. These farms that date back to the 17th century \u2014together with the Jesuit Block and Estancias of C\xf3rdoba in the C\xf3rdoba, Argentina|City of C\xf3rdoba\u2014 are all national historical monuments that were declared World Heritage Site in 2000.\n\nFile:Ischigualasto national park.jpg|thumb|left|Ischigualasto on the border of San Juan Province, Argentina with the Argentina province of La Rioja Province, Argentina running into the second through the canyons of Talampaya National Park\nFile:Cuesta del obispo 01.jpg|thumb|left|Cuesta del Obispo one of the Saltan entrances to the Calchaqu\xed Valleys. \n* Ischigualasto, also known as The Moon Valley, offers a strange landscape where the scarcity of vegetation and the more varied range vegetation of its soils plus the unusual forms of its rocks (geoforms) and mountains, make this a favorite place for tourists, both domestic and foreign. This provincial park, declared List of World Heritage Sites in Argentina by UNESCO, is located at the northern end of the San Juan Province, Argentina. It is also a major paleontology center became famous because it is the only place where it can be seen completely exposed and perfectly differentiated the whole Triassic period as complete and orderly, where the oldest fossils in the world were found. The Moon Valley, so named because of the diverse forms and colours of its landscape shaped by erosion, continues in the Argentinian province of La Rioja Province, Argentina with the Talampaya National Park. The Talampaya River Canyon reveals multi-shaped layers in its high red walls. Pink flamingos, Andean ducks, \u201cvicu\xf1as\u201d and \u201cguanacos\u201d cohabit freely in parks and natural reserves, while condors fly over the area. \nFile:Robben-001.jpg|thumb|Sea lions on the shores of the Patagonia\nFile:Jujuy-Purmamarca-P3120033.JPG|thumb|The Quebrada de Humahuaca view from Purmamarca in the Jujuy Province\n* Quebrada de Humahuaca\n* Calchaqu\xed Valleys\n* Iber\xe1 Wetlands\n* Puna de Atacama\n\nThe Quebrada de Humahuaca, the Calchaqu\xed Valleys, the Puna de Atacama (including Salar de Arizaro, the Laguna de Pozuelos Natural Monument, the Campo de Piedra P\xf3mez etc.), Ischigualasto, Talampaya, the Aconcagua, Caviahue and Copahue, near snow-capped mountains with temperate rainforests and glacial lakes; Andean Patagonia national parks, etc. constitute the tourist corridor called the Andean Footprint (Huella Andina) which is largely covered by National Route 40 (Argentina).\n\n\n\n\nFile:Mar-del-plata-playa.JPG|thumb|Two of the beaches of Mar del Plata during summer tourism season\nFile:Aconcagua.8.22.03w.jpg|thumb|The Aconcagua with snow; totally located in the Mendoza Province, it is the highest mountain in the world outside the Himalayas, and continues to rise.\nFile:Formosa Argentina.jpg|thumb|250px|Ba\xf1ado La Estrella near Las Lomitas\nFile:Palmar en Resistencia.jpg|thumbnail|300px|Caranday palm trees (Copernicia alba) in the access to Resistencia, Chaco from Corrientes\nMar del Plata is a tourist city with huge beaches on the Atlantic and the other beaches on the Seaside resorts of the Argentine Sea such as Necochea, Caril\xf3, Villa Gesell, Monte Hermoso, Pehuen-C\xf3, Las Grutas (in R\xedo Negro), Rada Tilly in Chubut; the Aconcagua (6,959 m), the highest peak in America. Its steep slopes are renowned and respected by mountain climbers worldwide. ; Las Le\xf1as; Talampaya National Park, of great geological interest; San Rafael, Mendoza heart of Mendoza Province, where the best wines of Argentina are made, with its imposing Atuel Canyon, the valleys of Barreal of Iglesia Department, in San Juan highlighting the adventure tourism. Whales-watching in Puerto Madryn on the coast of Argentine Patagonia.\nFile:Cuevas de Acsibi, Salta (Argentina).jpg|thumb|200px||Valley of the Caves in Salta\nOther very attractive destinations are the valley of Taf\xed del Valle|Taf\xed in Tucum\xe1n, ancient populations of Yavi and Iruya, the ruins of ancient pre-Columbian cities like Tastil, Tilcara, Shincal, the Pucar\xe1 of Aconquija, a fort built by the Kolla people.\nIn La Rioja Province, Argentina, the path of Riojan warlords, with Olta and Malanz\xe1n as main cities. In the first are monuments to \xc1ngel Vicente Pe\xf1aloza and the tango Caminito, inspired there, while in Malanz\xe1n is the birthplace of Facundo Quiroga.<ref>http://www.oni.escuelas.edu.ar/2001/catamarca/aconquija/_private/pucara.htm\nIt can also visit the oldest city in Argentina, the mother of cities Santiago del Estero, between the city Santiago del Estero halfway to San Miguel de Tucum\xe1n is located one of the most famous tourist destinations of mild winter in Argentina: the Termas de Rio Hondo|Hot springs of R\xedo Hondo.\n\nAre very attractive traditional events like the fair of Simoca in Tucum\xe1n, the Se\xf1or y Virgen del Milagro in Province of Salta or the pilgrimages to Luj\xe1n, Buenos Aires Province|Luj\xe1n and Punta Corral in Jujuy, the parade of faith to the Difunta Correa. An ample diversity of natural landscapes and dramatic contrasts such as the densely vegetated Yunga forests, or the mountains, hills and brooks of the Calchaqu\xed Valleys, provide great conditions for fishing for sport fishing. Sport fishing of sea and river (of trout and sea bass in the Tierra del Fuego Province, Argentina city of R\xedo Grande, Tierra del Fuego|R\xedo Grande, or Salminus brasiliensis in Paso de la Patria, Juramento, Lipeo, Iruya and Bermejo). For it part -it has been said- Ushuaia is a privileged access to the Argentine Antarctica, the picturesque Route of the Adobe and the Tat\xf3n Dunes in the Province of Catamarca; rugged adventure tourism in the provinces of Santiago del Estero and La Pampa or in the Yungas and Calchaqu\xed Valleys, the high Andean desert and jungles of Chaco, the northern Entre R\xedos (Montiel Forest) and Misiones.\n\nThe Buenos Aires Province is the most populous and largest province of Argentina (if territorial claims in the Antarctica and South Atlantic islands are not taken into account). The nations rail and road network fans out from Buenos Aires and into the province, the area centered on the Pampas. This region is characterized by its estancias (large cattle ranches) the oldest of them being featured in architectural styles, located in the middle of the Pampas. The province is also known by its many and different beaches in the coast of the Atlantic Ocean (the most visited being Mar del Plata). The hilly region of Tandil and Sierra de La Ventana (town) offers golf courses, paragliding rides and trekking. They are very different landscapes from each other and distant from the mouth of the Paran\xe1 River, which islands are also visited by tourists.\n\nMany ruins of the ancient Jesuit missions - some of which have been covered by the jungle - are located near Posadas, Misiones. The most well-known ruins are in San Ignacio Min\xed, 56&nbsp;km away from the province\u2019s capital. The ones in Candelaria, Nuestra Se\xf1ora de Loreto, Nuestra Se\xf1ora de Santa Ana and Reducci\xf3n de Santa Mar\xeda la Mayor, Argentina|Santa Mar\xeda are also very interesting. These Jesuit reductions were declared World Heritage Site by the UNESCO.\n\nFifty kilometers to the north of Col\xf3n, Entre R\xedos|Col\xf3n lies El Palmar National Park, housing the last samples of Yatay palm trees, which are almost eight centuries old. The city of Concordia, Entre R\xedos is connected to the city of Salto (Uruguay) through the Salto Grande Dam.\n\nThe Esteros del Iber\xe1, a humid zone of 700.000 hectares can be reached from Posadas, Concepci\xf3n or Mercedes. In Guaran\xed language|Guaran\xed, Iber\xe1 means "Shining water". Its lagoons cover 31,500 hectares, its marshlands 52,000, and its inlands 260,000. This eco-system which gives life to turtles, yacar\xe9s (caimans), monkeys, swamp deer, capybaras - the largest rodent in the world - and up to 400 bird species, besides an extraordinary flora, extends over one million hectares.\n\nThe city of Rosario lies on the banks of the Paran\xe1 River in the Santa Fe Province. It has developed into an industrial and commercial center and destination for a significant number of people on business. On its riverside promenade stands the National Flag Memorial (National Monument to the Flag), where the Flag of Argentina was raised for the first time. Parque Independencia has statues, a racecourse, and the Provincial History Museum.\n\nPunta Tombo is a coastal location where abundant wildlife congregates-specifically the seasonal breeding ground of large numbers of Magellanic penguins.<ref>C. Michael Hogan (2008) http://www.megalithic.co.uk/article.php?sid=18657 Pali Aike, The Megalithic Portal, ed. A. Burnham \n\nPeninsula Vald\xe9s is widely considered to be one of the best places in the world for the observation of wildlife, mainly sea mammals. Although southern right whales are the main attraction elephant seals, sea lions, Magellanic penguins and orcas are also well represented.\n\nLaguna del Carbon (the lowest geographical point in the Americas), Mount Fitz Roy, and the Petrified Forests National Monument, as well as the vast patagonian plateau.\n\n\n\nOverall Argentina has the following tourist circuits (north to south):\n* The Argentine Northwest, with contrasting landscapes like walking the Tren a las Nubes (train to the clouds) the arid and the cold of high embellished by curious landforms, saline, alkaline lakes where abound flamingos, geysers and high volcanoes, the transition zone of Calchaqu\xed Valleys and Quebrada de Las Flechas with mild climates as for cultivation of vine in Cafayate and good vegetation and, further east the dense rainforest called the Yungas. The spectacular cuestas as Cuesta del Obispo (in Salta) or the Cuesta del Portezuelo, Cuesta de Piedras Blancas and Cuesta de Capillitas in Catamarca or the Cuesta de Miranda in the Argentine province of Rioja.<ref>http://ar.noticias.yahoo.com/destinos-escondidos-caminos-catamarca-paisajes-imponentes-004200869.html\n* The Argentine Northeast that is characterized by its warm subtropical climate, its dense forests, parks, wetlands (marshes), large rivers with abundant fishing and big waterfalls.\n* The sphere of the Sierras de C\xf3rdoba and San Luis, with Mediterranean climate climate-type and abundant natural attractions.\n* The circuit of Cuyo (Argentina) with the highest mountains of America, rugged landscapes (canyons like the Atuel Canyon, or the Canyon of J\xe1chal River|J\xe1chal, several spectacular landforms: bridges like the Puente del Inca and castles like Reserva Provincial Castillos de Pincheira of natural rocks), ice formations like Los Penitentes (Argentina), caves and caverns, large volcanic extensions as in the Reserva Provincial La Payunia|Pay\xfan, ski resorts or pleasant valleys where stand crops temperate fruits, olive trees and vines.\n* The Pampas: a vast plain of temperate climate crossed by million cattle, dotted with numerous lakes and possessing a long coastline with long sandy beaches and dunes where thriving cities and seaside villages.\n* The Argentine Patagonia and more precisely Andean Patagonia, with beautiful landscapes who meet mountains always snowy, ice fields, glaciers, cold forests, large and deep lakes of glacial origin and very running rivers, winter sports centers and beautiful "alpine" aspect towns.\n* The Argentine Patagonia: large region of plateaus, mountains, canyons, moors and steppes whose coastline has high cliffs, gulfs, peninsulas where seabirds abound (especially penguins) pinnipeds, and whales.\n\n\nCarnival in Argentina are very important and usually take place during the last days of February (before the lent), at a time that remains still quite summer (summer in the Southern Hemisphere). Almost every carnivals in Argentina come from European carnivals in Spain and Italy, so it is spoken in them of murgas and corsos, with its masquerades and Gigantes y cabezudos although there have also influences of African elements from colonial times (the rate of drum in the murgas is almost obviously of African origin), and in the Quebrada de Humahuaca (in the northern province of Jujuy) and in the small town of Chamical (in Argentine La Rioja) are held a "carnavalito"  and a "chaya" more influenced by Andean American Indians. During the second half of the 20th century the cities of the province of Corrientes (mainly Paso de los Libres) and the Province of Entre R\xedos have had a strong influence from the Rio carnival in Brazil the same way as the Carnival de R\xedo in San Luis generally celebrated on the banks of Potrero de los Funes Dam Lake in Province of San Luis<ref>http://www.carnavalderio.sanluis.gov.ar/\n\n\n\n\nThese are the UNESCOs World Heritage Sites in Argentina:<ref>http://whc.unesco.org/en/statesparties/ar UNESCO World Heritage Sites: Argentina\n\n*Cueva de las Manos (Cueva de las Manos), Pinturas River|R\xedo Pinturas. Has prehistoric cave paintings (WHS since 1999).\n*Iguaz\xfa National Park, home of Iguazu Falls (1984).\n*Ischigualasto / Talampaya National Parks and its paleontology formations (2000).\n*Jesuit Block and Estancias of C\xf3rdoba in C\xf3rdoba Province, Argentina|C\xf3rdoba Province (Cultural Heritage) (2000).\n*Society of Jesus Mission (Christian) of the Guaranis: San Ignacio Mini, Santa Ana, Nuestra Se\xf1ora de Loreto and Santa Maria Mayor (1984).\n*Los Glaciares National Park and the Perito Moreno Glacier (1981).\n*Valdes Peninsula|Pen\xednsula Vald\xe9s, a marine wildlife preserve (1999).\n*Quebrada de Humahuaca, World Cultural Landscape (2013).\n\n\n90% of tourists come to Ministro Pistarini International Airport in Ezeiza, Buenos Aires, 35&nbsp;km from Buenos Aires, but to continue the journey to some of the destinations of the interior must move to Aeroparque Jorge Newbery (center of Buenos Aires), it is desirable that the trip or transfer (travel) between the two airports is included in the ticket.\n\n* Exchange: To date (October 2014) there official change and one parallel (called "blue") that is higher. At the airport there is a branch of Banco de la Naci\xf3n Argentina although a convenient way to get Argentine peso is an automated teller machine. As much of the world now uses currencies that can be changed are the USD (US dollar) and euro, then followed the Brazilian Real, the pound sterling and yen (in 2014 almost any other foreign currency is accepted for the usual change in Argentina). The best option in 2014 is to change dollar bills for pesos at exchange houses (it should be noted that from late 2012 to late August there is a large disparity between the official rate of the dollar in Argentina (which ranges between 8.50 Argentine pesos by US dollar and in the black market the price is called "dollar blue" (euphemism for dollar of black market) that comes to be around 15 pesos per US dollar, but it is inadvisable the clandestine change as many tourists that change with arbolitos (currency changers out of the legal system) are often cheated with counterfeit currency or directly be assaulted.\n* It is not suitable to do exhibit large amounts of cash or jewelry.\n* Gratuitys: in Argentina no is mandatory tip, however, is a habitual gesture, considering that the attention was correct then tip around 10% of what is consumed (in bars, restaurants, pizzerias, restobars and related and other services -server of hotels). In taxis and remises tip are a few extra pesos with the cost of the ticket. In bars, restaurants, cinemas, hotels and theaters around 5% to 10% of the cost of consumption or service.\n* Argentine cuisine: The national infusion is the Mate (beverage), followed by coffee. The fastest and most popular street food is the chorip\xe1n, which is a sandwich which uses chorizo in a cooked criollo style in situ on a grill using  "French bread" (In Argentina, french bread refers to white bread with wheat flour), the cooked chorizo of the chorip\xe1n is flavored with the typical chimichurri. Another fast food available in almost all bars and restaurants is the "lomito" which is a hot beef sandwich attached with lettuce leaves, slices of tomato, etc.; but more common is the sandwich of milanesa, similar to the above but with the flesh overflowing in breadcrumbs and egg and then fried. The "Churrasco" or the "costeleta" or the most succulent "bife de chorizo" are based on roast beef or hot griddle, which is usually accompanied by french fries, mashed potatoes or salads. The "Asado" or "barbecue" includes several cuts of meat on the grill, but offals or visceral as kidney and gut are not necessarily please the consumer is not accustomed. Also consume roasted goat meat, chicken and pork. Pastas as noodle, dumplings and ravioli are very accessible dishes and derivatives large influx of Italian people immigration. In the main cities of Argentina abound pizzerias which can be consumed, along with other dishes, pizzas in some cases very different from the typical Italian pizzas (some Italian travelers object that generally the Argentine Neapolitan pizza is not made with real mozzarella of Italian water buffalo but with Argentine musarela based on sheeps milk or even based on cow milk), plus pizzerias are very common the ice cream also tend to inherit the styles of the Italian gelateries. Other very common "boliches" in the Argentine cities are the caf\xe9s and cafetines (Spanish heritage but also with strong Italian influences) and breweries. In some places, mainly in towns of Argentine Northwest and of Cuyo (Argentina) can be found pulper\xedas and "pe\xf1as" in where predominates the Creole peoples folk food: asados, empanadas, tamales, locro, such establishments, especially if they are "Pe\xf1a (Argentina)|pe\xf1as", often have presentations of Argentine folk music and even tango. Higher level restaurants and Coffeehouse have a very complete menu with dishes more sophisticated. The Argentine wine are generally very good and economic.\n\nThe typical breakfast served to passengers in hotels is very simple, latte or tea, a couple of croissants and little else; is uncommon in  Argentina the "American breakfast" or "Fr\xfchstuck"; in rural areas breakfast usually is mate cocido or - few times admitted by the tourist - mate drunk in round with shared bulb.\n\nDinner times are from 21:00 onwards. \n\n<gallery mode="packed" heights="135" style="font-size:88%;line-height:120%" styles="font-size:88%;line-height:120%">\nFile:Foz de Igua\xe7u 27 Panorama Nov 2005.jpg|Iguaz\xfa Falls, one of the Seven Natural Wonders of the World.\nFile:Bariloche view.jpg|Summer view (in winter is snow and autumn in shimmering red and ocher leaves of trees) of Nahuel Huapi Lake, in the provinces of Neuqu\xe9n Province|Neuqu\xe9n and R\xedo Negro Province|R\xedo Negro.\nFile:Basecat.JPG|The Cerro Catedral in Bariloche during winter, R\xedo Negro Province|R\xedo Negro, is the largest ski resort of Latin America. This is an annual ranking produced by Ethical Traveler magazine, which is based on a study of developing nations from around the world to identify the best tourism destinations among them. The benchmarking uses categories such as environmental protection, social welfare, and human rights.\n\n\nFile:Train to the clouds in Salta -ARGENTINA- 003.JPG|thumb|Security with the Tren a las nubes\nThe U.S. Department of State warns travelers in Argentina that "drivers frequently ignore traffic laws and vehicles often travel at excessive speeds... traffic accidents are the primary threat to life and limb in Argentina."<ref>http://travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/cis/cis_1130.html#safety U.S Department of State Country Guide Argentina has the highest traffic mortality rate in South America, with Argentine drivers causing 20 deaths each day (about 7,000 a year), with more than 120,000 people injured or maimed each year. These deaths have included tourists from various parts of the world.<ref>See http://www.luchemos.org.ar/ingles/index.htm Luchemos por la Vida - Asociaci\xf3n Civil \n\n\n*Visa policy of Argentina\n*Culture of Argentina\n*Cuisine of Argentina\n\n\n\n\n\n*  http://www.indec.gov.ar Instituto Nacional de Estad\xedstica y Censos (INDEC), Encuesta de Turismo Internacional Row(id=496501, title=u'Emperor Entertainment Group', text_clean=u'\n\n\n\n\n\nEmperor Entertainment Group (EEG; ) is one of the largest entertainment groups in Hong Kong founded by Albert Yeung Sau-Shing in and established in Wan Chai in 1986, along with Music Icon Entertainment Limited and Emperor Motion Pictures, EEG operates under the major conglomerate Emperor Multimedia Group (EMG).\n\nThe major businesses of Emperor Entertainment Group (EEG) include the production and distribution of local and foreign records, music publishing, artiste management, concert organization, play production, movie and TV production, new media production as well as merchandise licensing and distribution. EEG now has emerged as one of the market leaders of the entertainment industry in Hong Kong.\n\nDedicated to nurturing young talents, EEG is the cradle of many of the hottest artistes in the Hong Kong music industry. Artistes under EEG management are frequent award winners of the territories various annual music award ceremonies. It is especially proud to be three-year consecutive winner of the Super Charged Award, which remains an unbreakable record up till now.\n\n\nEEG was founded by a well-known wealthy businessman in Hong Kong, Albert Yeung. The music label was originally called :zh:\u98db\u5716\u5531\u7247, until 1999. During the Fitto era, artist signed under the label includes Julian Cheung, Bondy Chiu, and the late Roman Tam. The label is affected by 1997 Asian financial crisis, which has caused the label, to be acquired by EEG in 1999. During the EEGs acquisition of Fitto, Nicholas Tse has become one of the artist rosters.\n\nMost EEGs artists are most popular among Hong Kong entertainment nowadays; some examples include Twins (musical group), Charlene Choi, Gillian Chung, Raymond Lam, Nicholas Tse, Leo Ku and Joey Yung. In the beginning, EEG was only involved in CD and DVD publishing; however, they have since diversified their business to include movie production and concert organization.\n\nA division of Emperor Motion Pictures, JCE Movies Limited is a film production and distribution company co-founded by Hong Kong star, Jackie Chan and Albert Yeung.\n\n\nEEG is involved in a variety of businesses, which include concert organization, CD and DVD publishing, advertisements, movies, etc.\nIt also owns EEG Showroom, which sells artist-related merchandise including signature notebooks and accessories. It also displays a range of special products not for sale.\n\n;EEG artists:\n*Nicholas Tse (\u8b1d\u9706\u92d2)\n*Jaycee Chan (\u623f\u7956\u540d)\n*Joey Yung (\u5bb9\u7956\u5152)\n*Twins (musical group)\n**Charlene Choi (\u8521\u5353\u598d)\n**Gillian Chung (\u937e\u6b23\u6850)\n*Raymond Lam (\u6797\u5cef)\n*Ken Hung (\u6d2a\u5353\u7acb)\n*Steven Cheung (actor) (\u5f35\u81f4\u6046)\n*Kenny Kwan (\u95dc\u667a\u658c)\n*William Chan (\u9673\u5049\u9706)\n*Edison Chen (\u9673\u51a0\u5e0c) (former)\n\n;Music Plus artists:\n*Leo Ku (\u53e4\u5de8\u57fa)\n*Yumiko Cheng (\u912d\u5e0c\u6021)\n*Vincy Chan (\u6cf3\u5152)\n*Sherman Chung (\u937e\u8212\u6f2b)\n*Deep Ng (\u5433\u6d69\u5eb7)\n*Wong Cho-lam (\u738b\u7956\u85cd)\n*Edison Chen (\u9673\u51a0\u5e0c) (former)\n\n;Music Icon artists:\n*Anthony Wong (singer) (\u9ec3\u8000\u660e)\n*Don Li (\u674e\u9038\u6717)\n*Mandy Chiang (\u8523\u96c5\u6587)\n*Keith Wong (\u738b\u51f1\u99ff)\n*Gene Gao (\u9ad8\u9060)\n*Alex Wu (\u6248\u4f73\u69ae)\n\n;Others:\n*Michelle Wai (\u8a69\u96c5)\n*Carlos Chan (\u9673\u5bb6\u6a02)\n*Benny Lau (\u5289\u5049\u6046)\n*Eva Huang (\u9ec3\u8056\u4f9d)\n*Kathy Yuen (\u6e6f\u6021)\n*Dylan Kuo (\u90ed\u54c1\u8d85)\n*Baby Q\n*Gladys Fung (\u99ae\u7693\u8a69)\n*Peter Bei-tak MAN (\u6587\u5f7c\u5f97)\n*Ocean Hai (\u6d77\u9e23\u5a01)\n\n;Publications\n*East Week\n\n\n* In 2003, Albert Yeung was again under investigation by the Independent Commission Against Corruption (Hong Kong), along with Hong Kong singer Juno Mak, for allegedly bribing TVB for the 2003 Jade Solid Gold Top 10 Awards.<ref>kklee105.com.
